instructions.2-3 Artist 1 new_instruction: Hi, I'm an artist. You can write code to make me draw almost anything. Use a few blocks to make me draw over the grey lines in the picture. (Each line is 100 pixels long)
instructions.2-3 Artist 11_instruction: Give the stop sign a border by making an octagon with 100 pixels sides.
instructions.2-3 Artist 12_instruction:
Create a circle to finish the eyeball!

If the artist turns 1 degree with each loop, how many times do you need to repeat the code to draw a circle? 180? 360? 500?
instructions.2-3 Artist 2 new_instruction: This house has a half-finished wall. Each side is 100, but the half-finished wall is only 50. Complete the wall.
instructions.2-3 Artist 2_instruction: This house has a half-finished wall. Each side is 100, but the half-finished wall is only 50. Complete the wall.
instructions.2-3 Artist 3.4_instruction: The jump block moves the artist without drawing. Draw the dashed line using both the jump forward and move forward blocks. Each line is 50 pixels long.
instructions.2-3 Artist 3_instruction: This hat is 100 pixels high. Draw a hat that is 70 pixels less.
instructions.2-3 Artist 3new_instruction: The red hat is 100 pixels tall. Finish drawing a black hat that is 70 pixels shorter. (Note: The width of each hat is 50 pixels.)
instructions.2-3 Artist 4_instruction: Help me complete the house for this cat.
instructions.2-3 Artist 5_instruction: Replace this code with a "repeat times" block to draw the same house using only 3 blocks.
instructions.2-3 Artist 6_instruction: This house needs a roof! Draw the triangle. Hint: all three sides are the same length.
instructions.2-3 Artist 7_instruction: Finish drawing the last set of windows on the school so that everyone in class can see outside. The sides of each square window pane are 25 pixels long.
instructions.2-3 Artist 8_instruction: Complete the rooms for each of the animals by splitting the rectangle into 2 equal-sized squares. The rectangle is 200 pixels wide and 100 pixels tall. There are many different ways to solve this puzzle, so have some fun!
instructions.2-3 Artist Assessment 1_instruction: Assessment: Finish drawing the last tooth. It is 25 pixels wide and 25 pixels tall.
instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 1_instruction: This hat should only be 50 pixels wide. Can you fix it?
instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 10_instruction:
The direction pad on my game controller is too narrow.

Can you make it wider by 10 pixels?

Try running the code first to see what's wrong.
instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 11_instruction:
My snowflake is falling apart!

Can you figure out what's going wrong?
instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 12_instruction: I'm supposed to add an ocean wave to this scene. Can you help me?
instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 2_instruction:
This code for the cat's whiskers is wrong.

Fix this code to draw whiskers that are all the same length.
instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 3_instruction:
My boat has a hole!

What do you need to fix to make the ends meet?
instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 4_instruction: What is the image that we're trying to draw? Finish connecting the dots using the proper lines and angles.
instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 5_instruction:
The code that we have for the leg and foot is wrong.

Can you fix it?
instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 6_instruction:
Looks like I'm sitting on a chair thatâ€™s missing a leg!

Edit the code to draw the last leg.
instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 7_instruction:
Looks like the C in code is drawn backwards!

Can you make it look like a C again?
instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 8_instruction:
My teacher says that I should finish what I start!

Help me finish my pinwheel. Can you figure out what's wrong?
instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging 9_instruction:
Something is off!

The code for this stem is wrong. Can you figure out how to get the artist to trace the stem the right way?
instructions.2-3 Artist Debugging Assessment 1_instru:
Assessment: Why does this square end up being 75 pixels too small on each side?

Where does the code go wrong?
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 1 a_instruction:
"Me zombie artist. Me love drawing!"

Help the zombie draw square glasses.

The bridge between the glasses is 25 pixels shorter than the width of the squares, which is 100 pixels.
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 1_instruction:
"Me zombie artist. Me love drawing!"

Help the zombie draw square glasses.

The bridge between the glasses is 25 pixels shorter than the width of the squares, which is 100 pixels.
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 10_instruction: Freeplay: Here are two functions, one to draw a big gear and one to draw a small gear. Use them to draw the inside of a machine!
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 11 a_instruction:
We've renamed the draw a square function to draw a hexagon, but it's still giving us squares! Can you modify the draw a hexagon function to draw a hexagon with 50 pixel sides?

Draw the image using the new function!
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 11.5 a_instruction:
Here's that same draw a hexagon function.

What happens if you loop the main program 6 times, turning 60 degrees each time you loop?
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 11.5_instruction:
Here's that same draw a hexagon function.

What happens if you loop the main program 6 times, turning 60 degrees each time you loop?
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 11_instruction:
We've renamed the draw a square function to draw a hexagon, but it's still giving us squares! Can you modify the draw a hexagon function to draw a hexagon with 50 pixel sides?

Draw the image using the new function!
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 12 Mike_instruction:
Functions are really great for drawing complex things multiple times.

Can you use the draw a flower function to fill the rest of the planter box? The plants are all 100 pixels apart.
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 12 a_instruction:
Functions are really great for drawing complex things multiple times.

Can you use the draw a flower function to fill the rest of the planter box? The plants are all 100 pixels apart.
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 12_instruction:
Functions are really great for drawing complex things multiple times.

Can you use the draw a flower function to fill the rest of the planter box? The plants are all 100 pixels apart.
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 13_instruction: We've provided you with four functions. Use them any way you like inside of one or more loops to make pictures that you can share with your friends. Press run to see an example.
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 2 a_instruction: Use the small green draw a square block to call this new function and create the glasses.
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 2_instruction:
Functions let you define new blocks!

We've moved the blocks needed for drawing a square into a function called draw a square. This time, use the draw a square function to create the glasses.

The squares are 75 pixels apart.
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 3 a_instruction:
Edit the "draw a square" function to draw glasses with frames that are 115px on each side.

The squares are now 45 pixels apart.
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 3_instruction:
Edit the function to draw a square with a side length of 115 to draw the bigger glasses.

The squares are now 45 pixels apart.
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 4 a_instruction: Now, put the function inside of a loop and add an extra turn to draw these three squares.
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 4_instruction: Now, put the function inside of a loop to draw these three squares.
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 7_instruction: Use the "draw a house" function to draw two houses using two different parameters. (Hint: the first house is 100 pixels).
instructions.2-3 Artist Functions 9_instruction: Freeplay: Here is a snowflake function. Experiment with it to create a winter scene! This is a free play level, so there is no puzzle to solve. Have fun!
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops 1_instruction: Can you make a hexagon with sides that are 100 pixels long to finish the cell? Remember, that means that you will only need to turn 60 degrees!
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops 10_instruction: What happens to the design when we make our final step forward half as long?
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops 11_instruction: Now let's put another loop around our whole creation! Don't forget to add an angle at the end of the outer loop.
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops 2_instruction: Now use a repeat block to make the cell a shell.
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops 4_instruction: Want to see what happens when we repeat that shape over and over again using a loop?
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops 5_instruction: Now let's make a small change to the loop and see how different our picture becomes.
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops 6_instruction: Add one more move and another turn inside the loop and see how your design changes.
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops 7_instruction: We can use loops to make all kinds of polygons. Can you create a rhombus inside this hexagon?
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops 8_instruction: Let's put both elements inside a loop.
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops 9_instruction: We're going to loop the same elements, but now we're going to add some distance between them. Use the same code as before, but add a step forward at the end of the outer loop.
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops New 1_instruction: Let's draw this robot's head! Can you make a square with sides that are 100 pixels?
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops New 10_instruction: Now let's connect a bunch of V's together in a loop.
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops New 11_instruction: Rebuild the code from the last puzzle, but this time, add a left turn of 30 degrees inside the loop. Now, repeat it 24 times instead of 8.
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops New 12_instruction: Draw a diamond with sides of 100 pixels.
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops New 13_instruction:
We are going to start you with some code (in grey) to make one diamond.

Loop the grey code to create a fun pattern!
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops New 14_instruction: Play around with the code for the diamond and see what other patterns you can make. Try changing how many degrees you turn and how many times you loop.
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops New 2_instruction:
Here is the same puzzle that we just solved, but this time, we can only use one move forward block and one turn block this time.

Can you use a repeat to solve this puzzle?
instructions.2-3 Artist Loops New 9_instruction: Draw a simple V (where both sides are 50 pixels) to complete the arrow.
instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 1_instruction: Put a repeat block around this whole stack of code to draw the pattern.
instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 10_instruction: Loop this code 12 times to complete the pattern.
instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 11_instruction: Loop this code 4 times to complete the pattern, turn 90 degrees after each circle.
instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 12_instruction: Loop this code 12 times to complete the curls.
instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 2_instruction:
Now loop the triangle 6 times.

After each triangle, you'll need to turn 60 degrees before drawing the next.
instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 3_instruction:
You'll need to loop the triangle 12 times to draw this pattern.

Divide the number of degrees in a circle (360) by the number of shapes you're drawing (12) to figure out how far to turn after each shape.
instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 4_instruction:
Loop this diamond 12 times to draw a flower!

Note: We'll use the same angle to loop 12 diamonds as we did for 12 triangles.
How much do you need to turn after each shape?
instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 5_instruction:
Fill in this building's windows using a nested loop.

The windows are 20 pixels long and 20 pixels apart.
instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 6_instruction: This dinosaur has 8 spikes running up its tail. Each spike is 30 pixels long. Loop the triangle 8 times, but make sure to jump forward after each one!
instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 7_instruction:
Loop this triangle 10 times to draw the sun.

You'll need to move and turn after each triangle.

You can figure out how much to turn by dividing the number of degrees in a circle by the number of triangles that make it up.
instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 8_instruction:
Now let's add some grass to our picture.

Each tuft of grass is 50 pixels apart.
instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops 9_instruction:
We'll finish this picture by adding our flower.

Loop the diamond 12 times to draw the flower.
instructions.2-3 Artist Nested Loops Free Play_instru: Free play, draw something cool with nested loops.
instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 1_instruction: Hi! I'm a bee. Help me get nectar from the flower.
instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 10_instruction: Purple flowers may have either 1 or 0 nectar. Be careful not to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any.
instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 11_instruction:
I wonder what's out there!

Help me fly around the yard and collect nectar only from the flowers that have some.
instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 12_instruction: Help me find all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible!
instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 13_instruction:
There's a lot happening here!

Use what you've learned to collect all of the nectar and then make the honey.
instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 14_instruction:
Let's put everything together!

Use what you've learned to help me collect nectar only from flowers that have it, using as few blocks as possible. Don't forget to make honey at the end.
instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 15_instruction:
This stair step pattern should look familiar.

Can you collect nectar only from the flowers that have some, using as few blocks as possible?
instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 2_instruction: I'm a hungry bee! Help me collect all of the nectar from the flowers using the fewest number of blocks.
instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 3_instruction:
Look at all of that nectar!

Help me collect the nectar and make the honey using as few blocks as you can.
instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 4_instruction: Help me collect all of the nectar from the flowers and make all the honey.
instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 5_instruction: Be careful not to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any. You must first check if the nectar is equal to 1 using the if nectar block.
instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 6_instruction: Check this flower with an "if" block to see if there is any nectar available.
instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 7_instruction: Collect nectar from each flower only if it has any.
instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 8_instruction: This field has red and purple flowers. Red flowers have a known nectar amount, but purple flower nectar is unknown. Collect all the nectar.
instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals 9_instruction: Collect all the nectar from each flower.
instructions.2-3 Bee Conditionals Assessment 1_instru: Assessment: Collect all of the nectar. Be careful not to try to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any.

What a sweet challenge!

"Bee" patient with this one!

You will need to fix a couple of things in this program to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.

Assessment: Now it's time to show what you know!

instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 1_instruction: Functions are blocks of code that perform a task. Use the "get 2 nectar" function to collect the nectar from each flower.
instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 10_instruction:
Purple flowers change between either 1 or 0 nectar each time you run the puzzle.

Create a function that collects nectar only from purple flowers that have nectar.
instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 2_instruction:
Functions are blocks of code that perform a task.

Use the get 5 function to get 5 nectars at a time.
instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 3_instruction: Collect all the nectar from each flower.
instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 4_instruction:
The move and get nectar function turns the bee, collects nectar, and then returns the bee to where it started.

Use the function to collect all of the nectar.
instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 5_instruction: There is now more nectar at the flowers. Edit the given function so that it collects 4 nectars and use it to collect all of the nectar from the flowers.
instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 6_instruction: Now use the same function to collect nectar from the three flowers.
instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 7_instruction: The flowers are now further away. Edit the given function and use it to collect all of the nectar from the flowers.
instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 8_instruction: Create your own function that gets 7 nectar, moves forward, and makes 7 honey. Use the function to collect nectar at each flower and make honey at each honeycomb.
instructions.2-3 Bee Functions 9_instruction: Create your own function that goes down a path, gets nectar, makes honey, and then returns the bee to the top of the path.
instructions.2-3 Bee Functions Assessment 1_instructi: Assessment: Use the given function to collect nectar from each flower.
instructions.2-3 Bee Functions Assessment 2_instructi: Assessment: Create a function to turn, move forward and make 3 honey, then return the bee to where it started and turn back.
instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 1_instruction:
Those flowers look tasty!

Collect nectar from each of the flowers using the fewest blocks possible.
instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 10_instruction: Can you use a while loop inside of two other loops to collect all of the nectar?
instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 11_instruction: Use while loops to collect all of the nectar from the flowers in this field.

instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 2_instruction: Collect all the nectar and make all of the honey using the fewest blocks possible.
instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 2A_instruction: This time, use a loop to gather all of the nectar.
instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 3_instruction: Collect nectar from each flower and make honey at each honeycomb using the fewest blocks possible.
instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 3A_instruction: Use a repeat loop to collect all of the nectar.
instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 3B_instruction: Now use the repeat block to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 4_instruction:
Such a busy bee!

Help bee collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey with the fewest blocks possible.
instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 4A_instruction:
How many times can loops help you in this puzzle?

Loops are your friend! Use a few of them to complete this puzzle with the fewest blocks possible.
instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 5_instruction:
The shape of this path is different than the others.

Can you collect all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible?
instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 6_instruction: Can you find the quickest way for the bee to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey?
instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 7_instruction: What a beautiful field of flowers! Help the bee visit each one. Can you find a way to do it with fewer than 7 blocks?
instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 8_instruction:
These purple flowers have different amount of nectar each time you run the puzzle.

Use the while nectar loop to collect all of the nectar.

This loop will run as long as the condition is true, in this case nectar > 0.
instructions.2-3 Bee Loops 9_instruction: The while loop can perform the same action as an if statement in a loop. Add a while loop to this code to perform the same task.
instructions.2-3 Bee Loops Assessment 1_instruction: Assessment: Use a while loop to collect all of the nectar from these flowers.
instructions.2-3 Maze 1_instruction: Can you help me catch the naughty pig? Stack a couple of move forward blocks below the when run block and press "Run".

instructions.2-3_instruction: Purple flowers may have either 1 or 0 nectar. Be careful not to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any.
instructions.2-3level1_instruction: Help the bird catch the naughty pig by moving it forward
instructions.20hr_farmer_stage9_1_instruction: Hi, I'm a farmer. I need your help to flatten the field on my farm so it's ready for planting. Move me to the pile of dirt and use the "remove" block to remove it.
instructions.20hr_farmer_stage9_10_instruction: I'm working late, so it's dark out, and I can't tell how large the piles are. Now I don't have all the options I used to have on the while block. Move me along the field, and if there is a pile, remove it
instructions.20hr_farmer_stage9_11_instruction: It's still dark outside. Move me along the field. If there is a pile, remove it, and if there is a hole, fill it in. Hint: use the dropdown menu of options on the "if" block.
instructions.20hr_farmer_stage9_2_instruction: Next, move me to the hole and fill it with TWO shovelfuls of dirt, using the "fill" block.
instructions.20hr_farmer_stage9_3_instruction: Move me to the pile of dirt and tell me how many shovelfuls to remove using as few blocks as possible.
instructions.20hr_farmer_stage9_4_instruction: Can you help me remove all four piles of dirt? Hint: use a repeat block if you can.
instructions.20hr_farmer_stage9_5_instruction: Help me fill in all these holes with 5 shovelfuls of dirt. Hint: you can put a "repeat" block inside the "while" block.
instructions.20hr_farmer_stage9_6_instruction: Remove all the piles of dirt, using as few blocks as possible. The new options in the dropdown menu on the "while" block tell me if I'm standing on a pile or a hole.
instructions.20hr_farmer_stage9_7_instruction: Wow, I found a really deep hole! I don't know how many shovelfuls of dirt it needs. Can you write a program that fills it until the ground is even?
instructions.20hr_farmer_stage9_8_instruction: Help me fill in the hole at the end of the field, using as few blocks as possible.
instructions.20hr_farmer_stage9_9_instruction: Make me remove all these piles of dirt. Try to use as few blocks as possible. Hint: try using a "while" block.
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_1_instruction: Can you help me to catch the naughty pig? Stack a couple of "move forward" blocks together and press "Run" to help me get there.
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_10_instruction: Ok, try the new "repeat until" block - it will repeat until I reach the annoying pig.
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_11_instruction: Ok, one last time for practice - can you solve this one using only 4 blocks?
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_12_instruction: Dear person. Me zombie. Me hungry. Must... get... to sunflower... Can you get me there with only 5 blocks?
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_13_instruction: Ok, this is similar, but slightly different. Can you do it in only 5 blocks?
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_14_instruction: Use the new "if" block to let me decide when to turn. Hint: you only need one more block, but learn how we set it up so you can do it on your own next time.
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_15_instruction: Ok, this is just like the last puzzle, but you need to remember how you used the "if" block and the "repeat" block together.
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_16_instruction: Me want sunflower! Use an "if" block to get me there with the fewest number of blocks.
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_17_instruction: Ok, let's do that again for practice - this isn't very different, but watch out for the chompers!
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_18_instruction: The "If-else" blocks checks a condition, and then does one thing OR another. To get me to the sunflower try to use this new block.
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_19_instruction: One more practice of the "if-else" block, can you get it right on your first try?
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_2_instruction: This pig is ruffling my feathers. Help me to find him!
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_20_instruction: Can you add just 3 blocks to help me solve a more complex maze? If you do it right, I can walk any curvy path no matter the length.
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_3_instruction: Trace the path and lead me to the silly pig. Avoid TNT or the feathers will fly!
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_4_instruction: Guide me to the green evilness! (Watch out for TNT)
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_5_instruction: Keep calm and help me to find the bad pig. Otherwise I might get angry!
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_6_instruction: There's a way I can get to the silly pig using only 2 blocks. Can you figure it out?
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_7_instruction: Try to get me to the green intruder using only three blocks.
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_8_instruction: Help me banish this bad piggy using the fewest number of blocks. Try using more than one "repeat times" block.
instructions.20hr_maze_stage2_9_instruction: When a block is grey, that means you can't delete it. Solve this puzzle using the "repeat" block that repeats 3 times. Try putting these 3 blocks inside the grey "repeat" block: move, move, turn.
instructions.4-5 Artist 1_instruction: Help me finish drawing my box. (Each line is 300 pixels long)
instructions.4-5 Artist 10_instruction: Press "Run" to try the code. Then, repeat it enough times to complete the drawing. The colors will be different every time.
instructions.4-5 Artist 11_instruction: Complete the green lines. The lines are 300 pixels long and 15 pixels apart.
instructions.4-5 Artist 2_instruction: Loop this code using the repeat block to complete the square.
instructions.4-5 Artist 3.5_instruction: Try to figure out what happens if you run this code (or just press "Run" and try it). Next, repeat the code enough times to complete the drawing!
instructions.4-5 Artist 3_instruction: This rectangular flower bed has a perimeter of 600. The long side has a length of 200. Draw the rectangle using as few blocks as possible.
instructions.4-5 Artist 4_instruction: How many degrees are in a circle? Loop the blocks to create a circle of colors.
instructions.4-5 Artist 5_instruction: What can we replace "???" with to make sure that the zombie completes this drawing using the loop provided?
instructions.4-5 Artist 6_instruction: This equilateral triangle has angles of 60, 60, and 60 degrees. Each side is 200 pixels. Complete the drawing.
instructions.4-5 Artist 7_instruction: This right triangle has angles of 30, 60, and 90 degrees. The slanted side's length (length of the hypotenuse) is 200 pixels. Complete the drawing.
instructions.4-5 Artist 8_instruction:
The halfway line on a soccer field is perpendicular to the sidelines.
This rectangle has a perimeter of 800 pixels total, and it is 240 pixels long. How tall is it?

Draw the bounds and the halfway line.
instructions.4-5 Artist 9_instruction: Draw the right half of this image so that the design is symmetrical. The triangles are equilateral and have sides that are 50 pixels long.
instructions.4-5 Artist Assessment 1_instruction: Assessment: Use a loop to draw the equilateral triangle. Each side is 300 pixels.
instructions.4-5 Artist For Loops 1_instruction: Put the numbers 1 through 10 into the width blocks and run the code.
instructions.4-5 Artist For Loops 11_instruction: Complete the "for" block so that it counts 0, 20, 40, 60, 80... 200.
instructions.4-5 Artist For Loops 12_instruction: What happens if you reverse the "from" and "to" numbers? Complete the "for" block so that it counts 200, 180, 160, 140, 120...0.
instructions.4-5 Artist For Loops 13_instruction: This design got started without a "for" loop and is taking too many blocks! Use a "for" block to complete the spiral. Hint: the last line length is 250 pixels.
instructions.4-5 Artist For Loops 14_instruction: Someone started the code, but then realized there must be a quicker way! Use a "for" block to replace the blocks and complete the triangular spiral. (Hint: the last line length is 300 pixels.)
instructions.4-5 Artist For Loops 15_instruction: Someone started the code, but then realized there must be a quicker way! Use a "for" block to replace the blocks and complete the hexagonal spiral. (Hint: the last line length is 200 pixels.)
instructions.4-5 Artist For Loops 2_instruction: This is a "for" block. Instead of typing 1,2,3... 10, the "for" block can repeat the blocks inside it and count the numbers for you. Place the number 10 into the "to" section of the "for" block.
instructions.4-5 Artist For Loops 3_instruction: How can we count from 1 to 50? Edit the "for" block.
instructions.4-5 Artist For Loops 4_instruction: Complete the "for" block so that it counts from 1 to 10 by 1.
instructions.4-5 Artist For Loops 6_instruction: Draw squares with sides of 50, 60, 70, 80, and 90 pixels. You'll need to use the "draw a square" function five times.
instructions.4-5 Artist For Loops 7_instruction: Draw the same squares but use a "count with" block to change the sizes. Place the "counter" block in the "draw a square" function. Hint: It's in the Variables category.
instructions.4-5 Artist For Loops 8_instruction: Can you complete the program by placing the blocks inside a "for" block that counts from 10 to 200 by 10? You can find the "for" block in the Loops category.
instructions.4-5 Artist For Loops 9_instruction: These circles are size 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, and 35. Draw the circles using a "for" block.
instructions.4-5 Artist Free Draw 1_instruction: Free Draw! Draw whatever you are inspired to create.
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 1_instruction: Use a repeat loop to draw this triangle.
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 10a_instruction: Put this code into the 'draw a snowflake' function and replace the 50 with the parameter 'size'. The function is already called on to make a snowflake that is 100 pixels.
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 10b_instruction: Use the 'draw a snowflake' function to create different size flakes. Hint: the first snowflake is 25 in length and each snowflake is twice the size of the one before.
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 11_instruction: This "draw a hexagon" function uses the "draw a triangle" function. Complete the hexagon function. (Hint: A hexagon has 6 sides, each 100 pixels long)
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 12_instruction: Complete the 'draw waves' function. Each wave is made up of one Upper wave and one Lower wave. Hint: Draw 5 blue waves.
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 13 Free play_instru: Here are some functions to draw planets, stars, rockets, and robots. Use them any way you like to make pictures that you can share with your friends.
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 14 Free play_instru: Here, we've provided you with several functions. Use them any way you like inside of one or more loops to make pictures that you can share with your friends. Click 'Run' to see an example.
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 15 Assessment_instr: Assessment: Use the "draw a square" function to create the squares. The squares are 50, 100, and 150 pixels.
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 2a_instruction: Now put these blocks into a new function called "draw a small triangle" and call on it.
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 2b_instruction: Now create a function called "draw a small triangle" using the provided blocks.
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 3_instruction: Now create the functions "draw a medium triangle" and "draw a large triangle". The "draw a small triangle" function is done for you. The triangles have side lengths of 50 (small), 100 (medium), and 150 (large).
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 4_instruction: This new "draw a triangle" function has a parameter and can do the work of all three functions before. Draw the same triangles using this new function.
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 5_instruction: Can you modify the "draw a triangle" function into a "draw a square" function to change the drawing?
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 6_instruction: Use the "draw a square" and "draw a triangle functions" to draw a house. (Hint: The square's sides are 200 pixels)
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 6b_instruction: Use the draw a square and triangle functions along with other blocks to create a house by adding them to the 'draw a house" function and calling it.
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 7_instruction: Use the "draw a house" function to draw houses that are 100 pixels and 50 pixels. The two houses are separated by 50 pixels.
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 8_instruction: The "draw a flower" function has a parameter that allows you to set the stem height. Set it to 200 and see what happens.
instructions.4-5 Artist Functions 9_instruction: Draw these 3 flowers. The first one's height is 100 and the next flower is always 50 pixels more than the height of the previous one. The flowers are also 100 pixels apart.
instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 1_instruction:
Draw this square using a loop.

Each side is 20 pixels long.
instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 10_instruction:
This code draws two rows of hexagons - loop the whole thing 4 times to draw the whole honeycomb.

You'll need to jump back 120 pixels in your outermost loop to make sure the artist doesn't draw off the screen.
instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 11_instruction: How many times do you need to loop this to draw a half circle?
instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 12_instruction:
If you create another loop like this one, but turn left instead of right, what happens?

Can you repeat all of that to draw this wave?
instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 13_instruction:
Now let's loop that whole thing four times to create this picture frame. Watch out for the corners - you can't just turn 90 degrees!

If looping a 3 degree turn 60 times makes a half circle, which of these blocks of code will make an additional quarter circle for the corners?
instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 2_instruction: If you place your square loop inside another loop, we call that a nested loop. What do you need to add as an outer loop to make sure all 15 squares line up next to each other?
instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 3_instruction: Now let's go one level deeper! We've nested that whole block of code into another loop, but you need to get the artist back in place to draw the next line. Which of these code blocks can you place at the end of the outermost loop to draw the whole grid?
instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 4_instruction: This diamond has 50 pixel sides and angles of 120 and 60 degrees. Use a loop to draw it.
instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 5.5_instruction: How many times do you need to repeat this block to draw the full grid of diamonds?
instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 5_instruction:
Repeat this code to make a row of 6 diamonds.

Notice that we changed our diamond code to repeat 3 times instead of 2 - why do you think that is?
instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 6_instruction: How many times do you need to repeat this block to draw the full grid of diamonds?
instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 7_instruction: Let's modify the code from the last puzzle to make this more complex pattern. Notice how the diamonds overlap now, try changing the first "jump backwards" from 100 to 50 (half as far) - now how far should the artist go in the second "jump backwards"?
instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 8_instruction: Use a loop to draw this hexagon with 40 pixel sides and 60 degree angles.
instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 9.5_instruction: Let's loop this code to draw two rows of hexagons. Notice how our second row is shifted to the right.
instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns 9_instruction:
Now repeat this code 3 times and draw the whole row.

Each hexagon is 80 pixels wide from the furthest points left to right.
instructions.4-5 Artist Patterns Free Play_instructio: Free play - try your hand at making a pattern of your own!
instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals - FC Test_instructi: The bee only wants nectar right now. Not all objects are flowers, so check underneath EVERY CLOUD to see if it is hiding a flower. If it is, then you can gather nectar.
instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 1 (copy 1)_instruct: The bee can't tell if this is a flower or a honeycomb. Gather nectar only from flowers, but first check if it is a flower or a honeycomb.
instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 1_instruction: This cloud is blocking my view! Check to see if there's a flower under the cloud, and only get nectar if there's a flower. Be careful, it can change!
instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 2 (copy 1)_instruct: The bee only wants nectar right now. Remember, not all objects are flowers, so check to gather nectar only at flowers.
instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 2_instruction:
More clouds!

Check underneath every cloud to see if it is hiding a flower before you get nectar.

Remember: Not all clouds hide the same thing!
instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 3_instruction: Now I just want to make honey. Some of these clouds might have honeycombs under them. Be sure to check each cloud!
instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 4 (copy 1)_instruct: The unknown object is either a flower or a honeycomb. Use the if/else block to collect nectar if it is a flower, else to make honey (because it is a honeycomb).
instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 4_instruction: Sometimes this cloud covers a flower, and sometimes it covers a honeycomb! Use the if/else block to collect nectar if it is a flower, else to make honey (because it is a honeycomb).
instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 5_instruction:
There will be either a flower or a honeycomb under each of those clouds!

Use the if/else block to collect nectar if there is a flower. Otherwise, make honey (because there is a honeycomb).
instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 6 (copy 1)_instruct: This purple flower may have either 3, 2, or 1 nectar. Here an if-else block is combined with another if-else block to create an if, else-if, else block. Complete the solution to collect the unknown amount of nectar.
instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 6_instruction:
I am not sure how much nectar this flower has, but I know it has either 1, 2, or 3 nectar.

Combine the conditional blocks (if and/or if/else) to only get as much nectar as the flower has.

Remember, the amount of nectar can change each time you run the puzzle!
instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 7_instruction:
These flowers can have 3, 2, or 1 nectar.

Complete the check purple flower function and use it to collect all of the nectar at the flowers.
instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals 8_instruction:
Write the function for check flower make honey.

Your function should check if the purple flower has 3, 2, or 1 nectar and get all of the nectar. Then, move forward and make honey.
instructions.4-5 Bee Conditionals Assessment 1_instru:
Assessment: This cloud is either hiding a flower with one nectar or a honeycomb that needs one honey.

Complete the get nectar or make honey function, then call it to collect the nectar or honey.
instructions.4-5 Bee Debugging 1_instruction:
These blocks are really bugging me.

Can you fix them?
instructions.4-5 Bee Debugging 2_instruction: Help the bee get the nectar and make honey.
instructions.4-5 Bee Debugging 4_instruction: These blocks don't work. What's the pattern?
instructions.4-5 Bee Debugging 6_instruction:
The purple flower has a different amount of nectar each time you run the puzzle.

Fix the blocks to get all of the nectar from the flower each time.
instructions.4-5 Bee Debugging 8_instruction: This function is fine, but it isn't used properly.
instructions.4-5 Bee Debugging 9_instruction: Why isn't the bee making enough honey?
instructions.4-5 Bee Nested Loops 1_instruction: Use a loop to collect all of the nectar.
instructions.4-5 Bee Nested Loops 2_instruction: Collect all of the nectar from each flower. Use a nested loop.
instructions.4-5 Bee Nested Loops 3_instruction: Collect all of the nectar by putting the starter code inside another loop.
instructions.4-5 Bee Nested Loops 4_instruction:
Collect all of the nectar from each flower and make honey at the honeycomb.

Use a nested loop.
instructions.4-5 Bee Nested Loops 5_instruction: Collect all of the nectar by creating a nested loop.
instructions.4-5 Bee Nested Loops 7_instruction: Put this loop inside another loop to create a nested loop and collect all of the nectar from the flowers.
instructions.4-5 Bee Nested Loops 8_instruction: Collect all of the nectar from these flowers by nesting a while loop. Replace the inner repeat times block with a while block.
instructions.4-5 Bee Nested Loops 9_instruction: Collect all of the nectar from these flowers by nesting a while loop inside a repeat.
instructions.4-5 Bee Nested Loops Assessment 1_instru: Assessment: Collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey using loops.
instructions.4-5 Bee Nested Loops Rows_instruction: Gather nectar from the rows of flowers! Use a nested loop.
instructions.4-5 Maze 1 (copy 1)_instruction: Dear person. Me zombie. Must... get... to sunflower.
instructions.4-5 Maze 1_instruction: Dear person. Me zombie. Must... get... to sunflower.
instructions.4-5 Maze 10_instruction: Can you get to the sunflower using only four blocks?
instructions.4-5 Maze 11_instruction: Can you get to the sunflower using only six blocks?
instructions.4-5 Maze 12_instruction: Ok, this is slightly different. Can you do it in only six blocks?
instructions.4-5 Maze 14_instruction: Get me to the pig! Use the Repeat until block.
instructions.4-5 Maze 2 (copy 1)_instruction: Get the zombie to the sunflower, but avoid the chomper!
instructions.4-5 Maze 2_instruction: Get the zombie to the sunflower, but avoid the chomper!
instructions.4-5 Maze 4 (copy 1)_instruction: Try the "repeat" block to use fewer blocks...
instructions.4-5 Maze 4_instruction: Use the "repeat" block to solve the puzzle quickly...
instructions.4-5 Maze 5 (copy 1)_instruction: Can you solve this puzzle using the fewest number of blocks possible?
instructions.4-5 Maze 5_instruction: Can you solve this puzzle using the fewest number of blocks possible?
instructions.4-5 Maze 6 (copy 1)_instruction: Can you solve this puzzle using the fewest number of blocks possible?
instructions.4-5 Maze 6_instruction: Get me to the sunflower using the fewest number of blocks possible!
instructions.4-5 Maze 7_instruction: Get the zombie to the sunflower quickly! Can you solve the puzzle in fewer than 11 blocks?
instructions.4-5 Maze 8_instruction:
Get the zombie to the sunflower using as few blocks as you can.
(Avoid the chompers!)
instructions.4-5 Maze 9_instruction:
Now we have a new block called repeat until.
This will let us keep looping commands until the zombie gets the sunflower.

Use the new repeat until block to solve this puzzle in as few commands as possible.
instructions.4-5 Maze Assessment 1_instruction: Assessment: Get to the sunflower using as few blocks as possible.
instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 1_instruction: Use the repeat until block to get the zombie to the sunflower.
instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 10_instruction:
Can you add just 3 blocks to help the zombie solve a more complex maze?

If you do it right, he can walk any curvy path no matter the length!
instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 2_instruction: Use the repeat until block to get the zombie to the sunflower.
instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 3_instruction: Use the if block to help me decide when to turn.
instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 4_instruction: Ok, solve this one just like the last puzzle, but you need to remember how you used the if and repeat until blocks together.
instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 5_instruction:
"Me want sunflower!"

Use an if statement to get the zombie to the sunflower with the fewest number of blocks.
instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 6_instruction:
"Eat sunflower!"

Use an if statement to get the zombie to the sunflower with the fewest number of blocks.
instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 7_instruction: The solution to this puzzle isn't very different, but watch out for the chompers!
instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 8_instruction:
The if/else block checks a condition, and then does one thing OR another.

Use this new block to get me to the sunflower.
instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals 9_instruction:
One more practice puzzle with the if/else block!

Trace it with your finger to see if you can figure it out on your first try.
instructions.4-5 Maze Conditionals Assessment 1_instr: Assessment: Use a repeat until and an if/else block to get me to the sunflower in as few blocks as possible.
instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 1_instruction: Complete the code to draw these triangles. The first one is done for you. Hint: 3 triangles in a 360 degree rotation.
instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 10_instruction: Draw the last row of stars on this flag by looping the provided blocks. The stars are 50 pixels apart, but remember that the stars themselves are 30 pixels wide.
instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 11_instruction: Can you draw these 10 squares of this sidewalk using a nested loop? Each square is 30 pixels.
instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 12_instruction: Can you draw these 36 triangles using a nested loop?
instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 2_instruction: Now nest this loop inside another loop to draw 10 triangles. This is called a "nested" loop.
instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 3_instruction:
Create a sun by nesting the starter code in another loop.

To get this cool design with a hollow center, you'll need to jump forward by the length of the triangle before turning.
instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 5_instruction: Loop the given code to create a windmill.
instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 6_instruction: Can you draw a hexagon by looping the triangle code?
instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 7_instruction:
Loop this design 10 times.

How much do you have to turn each time you loop?
instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 8_instruction:
Loop this shape 6 times.

How much do you have to turn each time you loop?
instructions.4-5 Nested Loops 9_instruction: Draw the teeth in the alligator's mouth!
instructions.4-5 Nested Loops Assessment 1_instructio: Assessment: Use a nested loop to complete the design.
instructions.4-5 While Loops 1_instruction: Move me to the hole and fill it with two shovelfuls of dirt, using the fill block.
instructions.4-5 While Loops 2_instruction: Move me to the pile of dirt and remove it with 5 shovel scoops, using the remove 1 block.
instructions.4-5 While Loops 3_instruction:
Use as few blocks as possible to complete this puzzle!

Move me to the pile and remove all the dirt, then move to the hole and fill it completely.
instructions.4-5 While Loops 4_instruction:
Wow, look at that!

I don't know how many shovelfuls of dirt this hole needs.
Can you write a program that keeps using the fill block until the ground is even?
instructions.4-5 While Loops 5_instruction: Wow, now there are two deep holes! Can you write a program that fills them both until the ground is even?
instructions.4-5 While Loops 6_instruction: Wow, now there is a large pile of dirt! Can you write a program that removes all of it so the ground is even?
instructions.4-5 While Loops 7_instruction: Wow, now there are three piles of dirt! Can you write a program that removes each of them until the ground is even?
instructions.4-5 While Loops 8_instruction: There is a really deep hole and a really large pile of dirt. How many shovelfuls of dirt need to be moved around to make the ground flat?
instructions.4-5 While Loops Assessment 1_instruction: There are a lot of holes and piles. Help me to fill and remove them to make the ground flat.
instructions.AlgPD DR Free Play_instruction: Create a function based on your own word problem.
instructions.Alien Defender_instruction: Project Idea: Make a defender game in Play Lab!
instructions.Alien Defender_2018_instruction: Project Idea: Make a defender game in Play Lab!
instructions.AllTheThings Applab - Turtle move with b: Add a button that moves the turtle when clicked. (Click to see full instructions)
instructions.AllTheThings: Pixelation - Lesson 14 - M: Make a 3x5 letter 'A'. The widget is setup with the incorrect dimensions. Your first task is to set the second byte to the 8-bit binary code for 5: 0000 0101. Then start entering pixel data.
instructions.AllTheThings: Pixelation - Lesson 15 - C: We start you out with the 4x4 image Maddie created in the video. Your task is to fill a 4x4 grid with colors using 12-bits per pixel. Here are the requirements: Row 1 - fill with shades of red. Row 2 - shades of green. Row 3 - shades of blue. Row 4 - shades of gray.
We start you with the 4x2 image Maddie was creating, but we've left out the last two squares. Finish off the image by figuring out which two colors are missing and encode them.
instructions.AppLab_test02_instruction: One sentence summary of the activity. Click to view full instructions.
instructions.Applab AllTheThings ResourcesTab AllReso: Draw a 1x1 square above and to the left of the turtle's starting position. Click to see full instructions.
instructions.Applab AllTheThings ResourcesTab MapRefe: Draw a 1x1 square above and to the left of the turtle's starting position. Click to see full instructions.
instructions.Applab AllTheThings ResourcesTab Referen: Draw a 1x1 square above and to the left of the turtle's starting position. Click to see full instructions.
instructions.Applab allthethings onRecordEvent_instru: Please sign in to test applab levels (By design, applab levels only work if signed in. Normally, we make people sign in, but this is only enforceable for a whole script and would be annoying to do for the allthethings script).
instructions.Applab test_instruction: This level is submittable. For testing only!
instructions.Artist - Nested Loops 1_instruction: Complete the code to draw these triangles. The first one is done for you. Hint: 3 triangles in a 360 degree rotation.
instructions.Artist - Nested Loops 10_instruction: Draw the last row of stars on this flag by looping the provided blocks. The stars are 50 pixels apart, but remember that the stars themselves are 30 pixels wide.
instructions.Artist - Nested Loops 11_instruction: Can you draw these 10 squares of this sidewalk using a nested loop? Each square is 30 pixels.
instructions.Artist - Nested Loops 12_instruction: Can you draw these 36 triangles using a nested loop?
instructions.Artist - Nested Loops 2_instruction: Now nest this loop inside another loop to draw 10 triangles. This is called a nested loop. Hint: All 10 triangles complete a 360 degree rotation.
instructions.Artist - Nested Loops 3_instruction: Create a sun by nesting the starter code in another loop. This is called a nested loop.
instructions.Artist - Nested Loops 5_instruction: Loop the given code to create a windmill.
instructions.Artist - Nested Loops 6_instruction: Can you draw a hexagon by looping the triangle code?

instructions.Artist Inspiration_instruction:
Free Play Inspiration: You've now learned everything you need to know to make a pattern like this! If this picture inspires you, try to make something similar. Otherwise, create something all your own.

Want to know how our inspiration pattern was made?
instructions.Auto Open Function Editor_instruction: You can call functions from inside other functions! Using your "shape" function as a base, create 3 house shapes each 20 pixels larger than the last starting at 50 pixels in length. Using a counter loop might be helpful.
instructions.Bee Recommended Blocks test_instruction: Purple flowers may have either 1 or 0 nectar, but you don't know which one! Be careful not to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any. Check if the nectar is equal to 1 by using the if block.
instructions.Bergeron Robot Maze1_instruction: Can you help me catch the naughty pig? Stack a couple of move forward blocks below the when run block and press "Run".
instructions.Big Game Animation 1 (copy 1)_instructio: Now that you've learned to write simple linear functions, let's work on using them to add some movement to our game. Click play to see what your game can currently do (not much!), update any variables you like, and then click finish to move on.
instructions.Big Game Animation 1_instruction: Now that you've learned to write simple linear functions, let's work on using them to add some movement to our game. Click "Run" to see what your game can currently do (not much!), update any variables you like, and then click finish to move on.
instructions.Big Game Animation 2 (copy 1)_instructio: The function 'update-target' function takes the target's current x value, and returns an updated value. Complete the 'update-target' function so that it adds to the x value each time it is called. The more you add to x, the faster the target will go.
instructions.Big Game Animation 2_instruction: The update-target function takes the target's current x value, and returns an updated value. Complete the update-target function so that it adds to the x value each time it is called. The more you add to x, the faster the target will go.
instructions.Big Game Animation 3_instruction: The update-danger function should work just like update-target, except that the danger should move from the right side over towards the left. Complete update-danger to make the danger fly across the screen.
instructions.Big Game Animation 4_instruction: At this point in your game, your danger should run across the screen from right to left, and your target should run across from left to right. They don't ever come back on screen once they've left, but we'll take care of that later. Take a minute to make sure your game is working like you want it to, and then click "Finish" to move on.
instructions.Big Game Booleans 1_instruction: When you last worked on your game we got our target and danger sprites to fly across the screen, but they never come back. Click "Run" to see how your game is currently working, and then click finish and we'll work on making those sprites reappear on screen after they've left.
instructions.Big Game Booleans 2_instruction: Go to the Functions section of the toolbox and complete the safe-left? function so that it returns true if the sprite's x coordinate is greater than -50. If you're successful you should see the Danger go off the left side and then return on the right side.
instructions.Big Game Booleans 3_instruction: Now that you've got safe-left?, let's fill in safe-right? - it should take in a sprite's x coordinate and return true if that coordinate is less than 450. Once your safe-right? is complete you should see the Target go off the right side of the screen and return on the left.
instructions.Big Game Booleans 4_instruction: Complete the onscreen? function so that it checks whether both safe-left? and safe-right? are true.
instructions.Big Game Booleans 5_instruction: At this point your Danger should run across the screen from right to left, your Target should run across from left to right, and they should both return to the opposite side, repeatedly. Take a minute to make sure your game is working like you want it to, and then click "Finish" to move on.
instructions.Big Game Collision 1 (copy 1)_instructio: When you last worked on your game we got our target and danger sprites to fly across the screen, but they never come back. Click run to see how your game is currently working, and then click finish and we'll work on making those sprites reappear on screen after they've left.
instructions.Big Game Collision 1_instruction: At this point you've programmed a video game with a moving Target and Danger, both of which return to the screen once they've left, and a Player that responds to keyboard input. Click "Run" to see how your game is currently working, and then we'll dig into the final missing piece - collision detection!
instructions.Big Game Collision 2_instruction: To move the player up and down, we'll need to use a conditional block to figure out which key is pressed and respond accordingly. Computers read keypresses as numeric key codes - the up arrow is 38 and the down arrow is 40. You can lookup other key codes in your student workbook. Edit the 'update-player' function so that if moves the player up when the up arrow is pressed, or down when the down arrow is pressed.
instructions.Big Game Collision 3_instruction: Use the Distance Formula, so the distance function returns the distance between the player's center coordinates (px, py) and another sprite's center coordinates (cx, cy).
instructions.Big Game Collision 4_instruction: Complete the collide? function so that it returns true if the distance between two points is less than 100 pixels apart.
instructions.Big Game Complete_instruction: A demo of the completed CS in Algebra Big Game project
instructions.Big Game Final_instruction: You made it! At this point your game should be fully functioning, take some time to enjoy your new game and make any final tweaks to it. When you're happy with the final product, click Finish and you'll have an opportunity to share a link to your game. Good work!
instructions.Big Game Player 1_instruction: We're getting really close to a finished game! Last time you worked on your game, you used booleans to make your Target and Danger return to the screen once they've left. Click Run to see how your game looks right now, and then we'll get to making your Player move up and down.
instructions.Big Game Player 2_instruction: Edit the update-player function so the player moves up when the up arrow (keycode 38) is pressed, and moves down (keycode 40) when the down arrow is pressed.
instructions.Big Game Testing_instruction: A demo of the completed CS in Algebra Big Game project

instructions.C3-Farmer While Loops 1_instruction: Move me to the hole and fill it with two shovelfuls of dirt, using the "fill" block.
instructions.C3-Farmer While Loops 2_instruction: Move me to the pile of dirt and remove it with 5 shovel scoops, using the 'remove' block.
instructions.C3-Farmer While Loops 3_instruction: Move me to the pile and remove all of it, then move to the hole and fill it completely. Hint: Use as few blocks as possible.
instructions.C3-Farmer While Loops 4_instruction: Wow, I found a really deep hole! I don't know how many shovelfuls of dirt it needs. Can you write a program that fills it until the ground is even? Hint: Try using the while loop this time.
instructions.C3-Farmer While Loops 5_instruction: Wow, now there are two deep holes! Can you write a program that fills them both until the ground is even?
instructions.C3-Farmer While Loops 6_instruction: Wow, now there is a large pile of dirt! Can you write a program that removes all of it so the ground is even?
instructions.C3-Farmer While Loops 7_instruction: Wow, now there are three piles of dirt! Can you write a program that removes each of them until the ground is even?
instructions.C3-Farmer While Loops 8_instruction: There is a really deep hole and a really large pile of dirt. How many shovelfuls of dirt need to be moved around to make the ground flat? Hint: Use the while loop for both.
instructions.C3-Farmer While Loops Assessment 1_instr: There are a lot of holes and piles. Help me to fill and remove them to make the ground flat.

instructions.CSD U6 params modify clouds_instruction:
Clouds

This program makes the clouds move when you blow on the sound sensor, but it's not finished.

Do This

  • Create a new function moveCloud(name) that will move any cloud.
    • (Hint: you will use almost all the same code as the moveCloud0 function)
  • Call your new moveCloud(name) function inside the event block, once for each cloud name.
    • (Hint: this is similar to how the loopCloud(name) function is called many times.
instructions.CSD U6 params modify clouds_2018_instruc:
Clouds

This program makes the clouds move when you blow on the sound sensor, but it's not finished.

Do This

  • Create a new function moveCloud(name) that will move any cloud.
    • (Hint: you will use almost all the same code as the moveCloud0 function)
  • Call your new moveCloud(name) function inside the event block, once for each cloud name.
    • (Hint: this is similar to how the loopCloud(name) function is called many times.
instructions.CSD U6 params modify planes_instruction:
Multi-plane Controller

This program moves the three planes using the board accelerometer and the on-screen check boxes. Right now, only the red plane works.

Do This

  • Create a new movePlane(name) function that can move any plane.
  • Call the movePlane(name) function inside the event block, such that it only moves when its checkbox is checked.

Challenge: Right now the planes move way too fast. Can you figure out how to change the code so they move more slowly?

instructions.Calc Circles of Eval .1_instruction: Youâ€™ll be writing a kind of code called Evaluation Blocks, because each block of code evaluates to a single value. Change the ??? in this code so that the block evaluates to 5.
instructions.Calc Circles of Eval .2_instruction: This Evaluation Block is a multiplication function which takes two numbers and returns the product of those numbers. Edit this block so that it multiplies 2 * 5
instructions.Calc Circles of Eval .3_instruction: Here's a function for addition which takes two numbers and returns their sum. Use this Addition Block to add 3 + 6.
instructions.Calc Circles of Eval .4_instruction: Here we've nested an Addition Block inside a Multiplication Block. Complete this code so it multiplies 3 by (4 + 1)
instructions.Calc Circles of Eval 1_instruction: Every mathematical operator (+, -, *, /, and so on) can be represented by an Evaluation Block in code. Change the Evaluation Block to match the expression.
instructions.Calc Circles of Eval 2_instruction: Use a Multiplication Block to complete this code.
instructions.Calc Circles of Eval 3_instruction: Complete the Evaluation Blocks to match this statement.
instructions.Calc Circles of Eval 4_instruction: This code is missing a couple of Evaluation Blocks - make sure you put everything in the right order.
instructions.Calc Circles of Eval 5_instruction: Complete the Evaluation Blocks to match this statement.
instructions.Calc Circles of Eval 6_instruction: Complete the Evaluation Blocks to match this expression.
instructions.Calc Circles of Eval 7_instruction: Complete the Evaluation Blocks to match this statement.
instructions.Calc Circles of Eval 8_instruction: Complete the Evaluation Blocks to match this statement.
instructions.Calc Circles of Eval 9_instruction: Complete the Evaluation Blocks to match this statement.
instructions.Calc Circles of Eval Free Play_instructi: Free Play: Try using the Evaluation Blocks to write some equations of your own. How does nesting the blocks in different ways impact their evaluation?
instructions.Calc Define Funcs 1 (copy 1)_instruction: Let's look at some more algebraic functions now. Here's a function translated from the simple algebraic function f(x) = x + 1. What would you expect this function to output if provided an input of 15?
instructions.Calc Define Funcs 1_instruction: Let's look at some more traditional algebraic functions now. Here's a function translated from the simple algebraic function f(x) = x + 1. What would you expect this function to output if provided an input of 15?
instructions.Calc Define Funcs 2_instruction: Write a function f that takes a parameter x and returns x - 10. Test your function using f(15).
instructions.Calc Define Funcs 3_instruction: We don't have to call our function f every time; create a function called times-ten that should take a parameter x and return x * 10. Once you've created the function, run times-ten(50).
instructions.Calc Define Funcs 4_instruction: Write a function called half that takes a number x and returns half that number. Once you've written the function, use it to calculate half(21)
instructions.Calc Define Funcs 5 - multiply 1_instruc: Oh no! We lost our multiply block! We'll have to create a function to multiply for us. To start off, write a function "f" that takes a parameter "x" and returns x*5. Test your function using f(3).
instructions.Calc Design Recipe 1_instruction: Let's use the Design Recipe to create a function called cube - this function should take in a Number and return that number to the power of 3. Make sure to write two example cases! When you're done, use your new function to calculate cube(7).
instructions.Calc Design Recipe 2_instruction:
Your school is holding a bake sale, and you need to track the cost of making each cookie, the money paid, and the total profit. Cookies cost $0.25 each to make, and sell for $1.50/cookie.

Write the function cost, which takes in the number of cookies you intend to sell, and returns the cost of making those cookies.

Test your function by calculating the cost of 42 cookies
instructions.Calc Design Recipe 3_instruction:
Write the function sales which takes in the number of cookies sold, and produces the amount of money customers spent to buy those cookies (each cookie is sold at $1.50).

Test your function by calculating the sales for 135 cookies
instructions.Calc Design Recipe 4_instruction:
Using the two functions we just wrote, write the function profit, which takes in the number of cookies you sold, and gives you back the total profit you make from selling your cookies, accounting for the cost of baking them.

Test your function by calculating the total profit for 15 cookies.
instructions.Calc Free Play_instruction: Free Play: Write functions and algorithms of your own design!
instructions.Calc Rocket 1 (copy 1)_instruction: In the last puzzle you wrote a contract for the function "rocket-height" that states it has a range of Number, domain of Number, and should return the height of the rocket traveling at 15 m/s after a given number of seconds. Let's write an example case now for the height of the rocket at 3 seconds.
instructions.Calc Rocket 1_instruction: In the last puzzle you wrote a contract for the function rocket-height that states it has a range of Number, domain of Number, and should return the height of the rocket traveling at 15 m/s after a given number of seconds. Let's write an example case now for the height of the rocket at 3 seconds.
instructions.Calc Rocket 2_instruction: Great, let's do one more example before writing the function - what should the rocket height be after 30 seconds?
instructions.Calc Vars 1.1_instruction: Here we've set the age variable to 17 years. Can you write an expression that calculates age in days?
instructions.Calc Vars 1_instruction: Variables allow us to name values so that we can easily refer to them repeatedly throughout our programs. Here's a variable called age. Set its value to your age and click run.
instructions.Calc Vars 2 (copy 1)_instruction: Here we've set the "age" variable to 17 - can you write an expression that calculates "age" in months?
instructions.Calc Vars 2.1_instruction: Here's a new variable called age-in-months. Use the variable age to set age-in-months.
instructions.Calc Vars 2_instruction: Can you write an expression that calculates age in months?
instructions.Calc Vars 3 (copy 1)_instruction: Can you add to this code so that it calculates how many hours there are in "age" years?
instructions.Calc Vars 3_instruction: Can you add to this code so that it uses the "age" variable to calculate age in hours?
instructions.Calc Vars 4_instruction: We can also set variables by using other variables. Let's say you have a brother who is two years younger than you - can you set a new variable "brother-age" using your "age" variable?

instructions.Course 4 Artist 10_instruction:
Click here to see the full instructions again!

Here is the code for an interesting shape. What happens when you repeat it multiple times, turning between each iteration? Notice that the turns in this shape add up to 420 degrees, which means that when your artist is done drawing, it will be facing a different direction than when you started. That new direction is exactly 60 degrees to the right of where you began.
instructions.Course 4 Artist 11_instruction: Now for a challenge! Feel free to use trial and error. You are not expected to get the image perfect the first time. Want to see more hints? Click here!

Otherwise, make a design all your own!

instructions.Course 4 Artist 4_instruction: How many degrees are in a circle? Fill in the repeat block with that number to create a circle of colors.
instructions.Course 4 Artist 5_instruction: Draw the other half of this design so it's symmetrical. The triangles are equilateral and are 50 pixels long. Hint: You may have to run the code several times to figure out all of the blocks that need to be added.
instructions.Course 4 Artist 6_instruction: Complete the code to draw these three, equilateral triangles.
instructions.Course 4 Artist 7_instruction: Now nest this loop inside another loop to draw 10 triangles. This is called a nested loop. Hint: All 10 triangles complete a 360 degree rotation.

instructions.Course 4 Artist 9_instruction: Loop this design 10 times and make sure to turn between each shape that's drawn.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Binary 1_instruction:
Here's a function that takes a binary string of 1's and 0's and instructs the artist to follow them from left to right, top to bottom. The artist will fill-in the squares when it sees a 1 and ignore the square when it sees a 0.

Run this code to see how the artist uses binary to draw this pattern.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Binary 1a_instruction:
Here's a function that takes a binary string of 1's and 0's and instructs the artist to follow them from left to right, top to bottom. The artist will fill-in the squares when it sees a 1 and ignore the square when it sees a 0.

Run this code to see how the artist uses binary to draw this pattern.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Binary 2_instruction: Which of these binary strings could you loop 8 times to draw this image?
instructions.Course 4 Artist Binary 3_instruction: Can you draw this pattern by looping just three binary digits (0s and 1s)?
instructions.Course 4 Artist Binary 4_instruction: Each binary string represents one row of this picture. Can you rearrange them so it draws a smiley face instead of a frowny face?
instructions.Course 4 Artist Binary 5_instruction: Which 6 digit binary string, repeated 11 times, will draw this image?
instructions.Course 4 Artist Binary 6_instruction: What is the shortest binary string that you can repeat to draw this image?
instructions.Course 4 Artist Binary Free Play 2_instr: Free Play: Here's a blank canvas for you to draw on. Have fun!
instructions.Course 4 Artist Binary Free Play 2a_inst:
Here's a higher resolution canvas to draw on - 16 pixels by 16 pixels!

See what happens when we start to get creative with the bits?
instructions.Course 4 Artist Binary Free Play_instruc: Free Play: Draw whatever you like with binary!
instructions.Course 4 Artist Binary pre1_instruction: Use the blocks below to have the artist draw "01010101" in binary in the first row.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Binary ryan_instruction:
Binary is a way of representing information using only two options. Here, we're going to use the options "off" (represented by the number 0) and "on" (represented by the number 1).

We've provided you with a grid of "pixels" that you can walk through and make designs by turning on only certain squares. Can you have the artist draw "01010101" in binary in the first row?
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Functions 10_instru: Let's Step it up a little, can you draw a Star shape using the "Draw a Square Line" function? Good luck!
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Functions 11_instru: Let's Step it up a little, can you draw a Star shape using the "Draw a Square Line" function? Good luck!
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 1_instruction: Use a repeat block to draw this triangle that is 50 pixels wide.
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 10_instruction: Free Play Time! Have fun drawing whatever you like with the blocks you have learned how to use
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 11_instruction: Remember back in a previous stage when we used a variable to control the number of sides in a shape? We are going to do the same thing with the counter variable now. This pattern starts with a triangle and adds one side at a time until it draws a decagon (10 sides). Each side should be 100 pixels long.
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 11a_instructio:
Let's put it all together! Using your knowledge of for loops and the counter variable, create this drawing where each shape has two more sides than the last. Make sure that each side is 10 times as long as the number of sides in the polygon.

Very little of the code has been provided for you.
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 12_instruction: That looked pretty cool, but now I'd like to draw each shape next to the last one. This time each side is 20 pixels. Use a jump block to jump forward 40 pixels after each shape.
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 13_instruction: Hmmm, those shapes are getting bigger every time! Didn't we already solve this problem with variables? How can we use the counter variable to make the sides smaller as there are more of them? Instead of moving forward by a set amount, try moving forward (100 / counter) pixels.
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 14_instruction: If you turn a little bit more or less than you normally would for a shape, it creates a neat effect. Try using some of the code from the last level, but turning 89 degrees to create this twisted square spiral.
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 15_instruction: Free Play: Try making some drawings of your own using "for loops". We've added a few useful variables for you as well.
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 2_instruction: I've put the code for drawing a triangle inside a for loop that counts from 50 to 100 by 10. NOTE: Make sure you look at the code before you hit "Run".
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 3_instruction: Use the last puzzle as a reference to complete this one. The smallest triangle has 20 pixel sides, the largest has 200 pixel sides, and each triangle is 20 pixels larger than the last.
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 4_instruction: How would you modify what you've learned to draw these squares? They start at 15 pixels long, the largest is 300 pixels long, and each square is 15 pixels larger than the last.
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 5_instruction: Good job on the last puzzle! Let's use that "counter" variable block again to draw this cool picture.
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 6_instruction: Free Play! Try using a for loop to draw a growing shape pattern of your own design.
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 6a_instruction: Make three small changes to the code from the last level to get this!
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 7_instruction: What happens if you remove the "Repeat 3" from this algorithm, keeping the "move" and "turn" blocks in the for loop? In this spiraling triangle, each side is 20 pixels longer than the last.
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 8_instruction:
Just one little change to the code from the last image can create this drawing. Can you figure out what that change is?

Hint: You need to remove something!
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 8a_instruction: Just one little change to the code from the last image can create this image. Can you figure out what that change is?
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops 9_instruction: Can you make a spiral? Move forward from 1 to 75 pixels, increasing by 1 pixel each time.
instructions.Course 4 Artist For Loops Challenge_inst: Challenge: Can you figure out how to use all of the things you've learned to create this image of polygons, all with 40 pixel sides?

Hint: To get yourself to the upper-right corner, try jumping in a pattern that makes just 3/8 of the octagon.

instructions.Course 4 Artist Functions 3_instruction: Using the "draw a square" function block, can you draw this picture? Hint: each square is 120 pixels apart.

Click on the "Functions" block in the tool box, name it "draw a triangle", then create a triangle as you have done before with the Action and Loops blocks. Then click on the Save and Close in the upper right hand corner. Hint: Create a triangle that is 100 pixels in length. Good luck!
