instructions.Course 4 Artist Params 10_instruction: You can call functions from inside other functions! Using your "shape" function as a base, create 3 house shapes each 20 pixels larger than the last starting at 50 pixels in length. Using a counter loop might be helpful.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Params 11_instruction: How about a function called "pinwheel" that takes three parameters - "sides," "length" and "repeat." You can calculate how much to turn after each shape using the same math you used to figure out the turns for a shape of "sides". Can you recreate this picture? Here's a tip each shape is 100 pixel's in length.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Params 12_instruction: Use your "pinwheel" function to draw each of these shapes. The side length for each image is 50.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Params 13_instruction: Freeplay: Here are the functions you've written, and some more for you to play with. Draw something awesome!
instructions.Course 4 Artist Params 2_instruction: That triangle function would be a whole lot more useful if it could draw triangles of different sizes. I've added a parameter for line length, but it doesn't do anything yet. Can you update the function so it uses the "length" parameter when it draws each side? The triangle sizes are 150 pixels, 75 pixels and 25 pixels.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Params 3_instruction: Awesome, can you draw each of these triangles with that new function? The first is 25 pixels long, the second is 50, and the third is 75.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Params 4_instruction: Can you add a new function called square? It should also take a length parameter, just like the triangle. This time draw 3 squares 25, 50 and 75 pixels in length,100 pixels apart.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Params 5_instruction: Use both of your new functions to draw this picture. To make this easier you use a loop with a "counter" parameter.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Params 6_instruction: Let's edit this "draw a shape" function. It already has a "length" parameter. Now, let's edit the function to also add a "sides" parameter. Remember the angle to turn for a given shape is 360 divided by the sides it has. Hint: lengths for each shape are the triangle is 100 pixels, the hexagon is 25 pixels and the square is 50 pixels.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Params 7_instruction: Can you draw these shapes by filling in the "???" The square and triangle are 100 pixels in size while the hexagon is 75 pixels in size.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Params 8_instruction: Can you figure out how to draw this shape? Here's a hint create a new function with 6 sides called a hexagon.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Params 9_instruction: Do you remember when we used the counter loop but removed a loop within? Let's have some fun and use the "draw a shape" function with "sides" and "length" parameters. Can you re create these shapes? The square counter should be 5/100/5, the triangle counter should be 10/100/10 and the hexagon is 2/100/2.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Var 9_instruction: Here's the algorithm to draw a triangle, modify it so it uses the "sides" variable instead. Replace the number 3 with the "sides" variable. Hint: remember to use the "set sides to" block.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Vars 1_instruction:
Let's draw an equilateral triangle.

It has to be exactly 100 pixels long on each side.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Vars 10_instruction: Here's an algorithm that draws a triangle out of smaller triangles. Can you modify it so that it uses the "sides" variable to draw each triangle? Look through the code, and every time you see the number 3, replace it with your "sides" variable. Remember to use the "set sides" block.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Vars 11_instruction: Hereâ€™s more complicated code using the same concepts from the last puzzle - what should you set the "sides" variable to in order to draw this picture made of squares?
instructions.Course 4 Artist Vars 12_instruction: Let's set the "sides" variable to 5. The more sides we add to this algorithm, the bigger this whole pattern gets! Notice that there is another variable called "length". We can now use that wherever we have a "move forward." Set the "length" variable to 75 for this shape.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Vars 13_instruction: When a shape has lots of sides, each side needs to be shorter if you want the whole pattern to fit on the screen. Let's recreate the algorithm for this amazing pattern, but instead of manually setting the length variable, let's use a math block with the sides variable inside to make sure that each shape fits correctly. The perimeter of each polygon is 300 pixels. Need some hints? Click here.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Vars 14_instruction:
Free Play: Check it out! Now your algorithm is nested within one more loop. Experiment with changing the values of your two variables to draw cool patterns.

For even more effect, try playing with color! Use random colors inside loops to see how it changes your design.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Vars 2_instruction: Instead of using "move forward by 150," the "move" block is now referencing a variable called "length." Can you set "length" to 150 to draw this new triangle?
instructions.Course 4 Artist Vars 3_instruction: Here's a loop that draws a square, but something's missing. Can you fix it so that it uses the variable "length" to figure out how long each side should be?
instructions.Course 4 Artist Vars 4_instruction: Now I want to make a rectangle that is twice as tall as it is wide. We've got a variable called "width" that needs to be set to 100. Can you use the math blocks to complete the code?
instructions.Course 4 Artist Vars 5_instruction: Use the variable "sides" to control how many times this loop gets run.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Vars 6_instruction:
Hereâ€™s some code that can draw any regular polygon. Thereâ€™s a new variable called sides that is set to 4. Can you use the sides variable (along with the math block) to turn the right amount regardless of how many sides there are in the polygon?

Click here to go back to the hint!
instructions.Course 4 Artist Vars 7_instruction:
Use what you learned in the last puzzle to create this hexagon using the "sides" variable.

See how you could change just one value to draw a triangle, square, pentagon, or octagon?
instructions.Course 4 Artist Vars 8_instruction: Free Play: Experiment with the number of sides this shape has. Can you change the algorithm so that the overall size of the shape stays the same, no matter how many sides it has? Hint: If you divide your starting length by the number of sides, the length of each side will get shorter as the number of sides gets higher.
instructions.Course 4 Artist Vars 9_instruction: Modify this algorithm so it uses the "sides" variable instead of a fixed number to draw a triangle. Don't forget to use the "set sides to" block.
instructions.Course 4 Bee 1_instruction:
The bee can't tell what's under the cloud!

Use the if block to check whether there is a flower under the cloud.

Get nectar one time, ONLY if there is a flower.
instructions.Course 4 Bee 2_instruction: Use the "if/else" block to check each object to see if it's a flower or a honeycomb . If it's a flower, collect one nectar...otherwise, make one honey!
instructions.Course 4 Bee 3_instruction: The unknown object is either a flower or a honeycomb. This time, use the if/else block to collect one nectar if it is a flower, else make one honey (because then it would be a honeycomb).
instructions.Course 4 Bee 4_instruction: This purple flower may have either 3, 2, or 1 nectar. Here an if/else block is combined with another if/else block to create an "if/else-if/else" statement. Complete the solution to collect the unknown amount of nectar.
instructions.Course 4 Bee 5_instruction: This purple flower may have either 3, 2, or 1 nectar. Add an if-else block to create an if, else-if, else block. Complete the solution to collect the unknown amount of nectar.
instructions.Course 4 Bee 6_instruction: This purple flower may have either 3, 2, or 1 nectar. Create an if, else-if, else block to collect the unknown amount of nectar.
instructions.Course 4 Bee 7_instruction: Use everything you have learned so far to collect all the nectar. The purple flower may have either 3, 2, or 1 nectar.
instructions.Course 4 Bee For Loops 1_instruction: Use a loop to collect the nectar from each flower.
instructions.Course 4 Bee For Loops 10_instruction: If your loop is counting down, the increment is subtracted from your counter variable each loop. What should your increment be to collect 9, then 6, and then 3 nectar?
instructions.Course 4 Bee For Loops 11_instruction: What's wrong with this loop? See if you can fix it and make the bee collect all the nectar.
instructions.Course 4 Bee For Loops 2_instruction: Here's a new kind of loop, called the "for" loop. This particular for loop will count from 1 to 5 by 1, and run the contents of the loop each time it counts. Help the Bee get the nectar.
instructions.Course 4 Bee For Loops 3_instruction: You can solve this puzzle by using a for loop to count from 1 to 3 by 1. Now let's go get some nectar!
instructions.Course 4 Bee For Loops 4_instruction: Collect all of the nectar from these flowers. I wonder if there's an easier way to do this...
instructions.Course 4 Bee For Loops 5_instruction: Ah, the for loop makes this much easier! Using the "counter" variable from the for loop to loop the "get nectar" block the same number of times as the loop. Whew! That's a lot of loops. All the code you need it there, take a look at how it is put together then click on Run and see how it works.
instructions.Course 4 Bee For Loops 6_instruction: You can also use a for loop to count down. Try gathering this nectar by counting down from 5 to 1 by 1.
instructions.Course 4 Bee For Loops 7_instruction: Use your for loop "counter" variable to control how far to move horizontally.
instructions.Course 4 Bee For Loops 8_instruction: Can you use the loop variable to control movement and nectar collection?
instructions.Course 4 Bee For Loops 9_instruction: The last number in your for loop is called the "increment," and each time the loop is run the counter variable changes by the increment. Try collecting these flowers using an increment of 2.
instructions.Course 4 Bee Loops 5 NEW_instruction: Here are three flowers. Can you find the pattern of instructions that you need to repeat 3 times to collect the nectar with the fewest number of blocks?
instructions.Course 4 Bee Loops 5a NEW_instruction: Now, use loops to help the bee collect all the nectar on its way to the honeycomb with as few blocks as possible. When you get there, don't forget to make honey!
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 1_instruction: Write a sequence to collect all of the nectar using get 3 nectar which turns, moves to collect the nectar, and then returns to the original location.
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 2_instruction: Modify the "get 3 nectar" function so it makes me turn right instead of left to the flowers.
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 3 (copy 1)_instructi: Now there are flowers on both sides! Maybe you can use a parameter so that the same function works for flowers on either side. I've added a parameter called "direction" to the function. If the "direction" parameter equals 0 I should turn left, if it's 1 I should turn right.
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 3_instruction: Now there are flowers on both sides! We've added variables called "left" and "right" for you to use, and added a parameter called "direction" to "get 3 nectar". Edit "get 3 nectar" so that the bee turns the correct direction when the variables "left" or "right" are passed into the function.
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 4 (copy 1)_instructi: Try using your new function to collect all of the flowers. Remember, 0 = left and 1 = right.
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 4 - Two WhenRun_inst: Try using your new function to collect all of the flowers. Remember to use the left and right variables.
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 4 backup_instruction: Wouldn't it be nice if we could collect all of these nectars with the a single function? Try adding a new parameter to your function called "nectars" to control the amount of nectar to collect. You'll probably want to rename the function too!
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 4_instruction: Try using your new function to collect nectar from all of the flowers. Remember to use the left and right variables.
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 5_instruction: Let's start from scratch - can you create a new function called "get 5 nectar" with a direction parameter?
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 6 (copy 1)_instructi: Try using your new function to collect all of this nectar.
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 6_instruction: Wouldn't it be nice if we could collect all of these nectars with a single function? Try adding a new parameter to your function called "nectar units" to control the amount of nectar to collect. You'll probably want to rename the function too!
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 7 (copy 1)_instructi: Try using your new function to collect all of this nectar.
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 7_instruction: Try using your new function to collect all of this nectar.
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 8 Clone 2_instructio: Oooh, now there's honey to deal with too! How could you update your function to either get nectar or make honey.
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 8 Clone_instruction: Oooh, now there's honey to deal with too! How could you update your function to either get nectar or make honey.
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 8 clone 3_instructio: Oooh, now there's honey to deal with too! How could you update your function to either get nectar or make honey.
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 8 new_instruction: Oooh, now there's honey to deal with too! How could you update your function to either get nectar or make honey.
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params 8_instruction: Challenge: Now there's honey to deal with too! Rewrite your function to use both the number of honey units and the number of nectar units. How would you use those numbers to decide what you should do?
instructions.Course 4 Bee Params Ex_instruction: Try using your new function to collect all of this nectar.
instructions.Course 4 Binary 1_instruction: Here's a function that takes a binary string of 1's and 0's and instructs the farmer to turn on the go from left to right, top to bottom, turning on the squares where the number has a zero. Run the code provided to see how the farmers uses binary to draw an image.
instructions.Course 4 Binary 2_instruction: What binary string could you loop 8 times to draw this image? Hint: the number "1" fills a hole.
instructions.Course 4 Binary 3_instruction: Can you draw this pattern by looping a single binary string?
instructions.Course 4 Binary 5 (copy 1)_instruction: Which binary string, repeated 10 times, will draw this image?
instructions.Course 4 Binary 5_instruction: Which binary string, repeated 10 times, will draw this image?
instructions.Course 4 Binary 6 (copy 1)_instruction: Which binary string, repeated 10 times, will draw this image?
instructions.Course 4 Binary 6_instruction: Which binary string, repeated 10 times, will draw this image?
instructions.Course 4 Binary 7_instruction: Which binary string, repeated 10 times, will draw this image?
instructions.Course 4 Binary 8_instruction: You can complete the most of this image by looping a 5 bit binary number - then you'll need one more 4 bit number to get the bottom right-hand corner.
instructions.Course 4 EC 1a_instruction: No rules. No clues. Just the challenge!
instructions.Course 4 EC 1b_instruction: No rules. No clues. Just the challenge!
instructions.Course 4 EC 2a_instruction: No rules. No clues. Just the challenge!
instructions.Course 4 EC 2b_instruction: No rules. No clues. Just the challenge!
instructions.Course 4 EC 2c_instruction: No rules. No clues. Just the challenge!
instructions.Course 4 EC 2d_instruction: No rules. No clues. Just the challenge!
instructions.Course 4 EC 3_instruction: Use what you learned in the previous level to draw an image like this. Note: The code becomes more simple if you incorporate parameters.
instructions.Course 4 EC 3a_instruction: Extreme Challenge: No rules. No clues. Just the challenge!
instructions.Course 4 Maze 1_instruction: Get the angry bird to the pig!
instructions.Course 4 Maze 3_instruction: Program the angry bird to get to the pig.
instructions.Course 4 Maze 4_instruction: Try the "repeat" block to use fewer blocks when solving this puzzle...
instructions.Course 4 Maze 5_instruction: Can you solve this puzzle using the fewest number of blocks possible?
instructions.Course 4 Maze 6_instruction: Can you solve this puzzle using the fewest number of blocks possible?
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab For Loops 2_instructio: This time, let's try counting the odd numbers from 1 to 100.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 1_instruction: Here's a function called jump that causes your main character to jump up 100 pixels. Run the program and use the jump function to collect all of the flags by moving the dog with the arrow keys.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 10_instruction:
We've added one last function for you.

Use an "if" statement to program your game to call the "level_up" function only when "player_score" becomes greater than a certain number.

For example: "player_score" > 6

Play the game, and make it to level 3 to move to the next puzzle.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 2_instruction:
Now we've got flags that are too high for our current jump! Let's use both the "up" and "down" arrows so that we can have multiple jump heights.

We need to add a parameter to our jump function called "height". The up arrow should cause the dog to jump 200 pixels and the down arrow should make it jump only 100 pixels.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 3_instruction: We have added another parameter to the jump function so that we can use it with other actors. Each actor is represented by a number, starting from one. Edit the "jump" function so that it uses the "actor" parameter to make the correct character jump.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 4_instruction:
Here's a function called patrol.

Edit patrol to move Cat up 400 pixels and then down 400 pixels.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 5_instruction: Edit the the "patrol" function to add an "actor" parameter, so that we can call it for each of the actors on the screen. Remember, the actors correspond to numbers 1, 2, and 3.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 6_instruction: Add another parameter called "speed" to the "patrol" function. Try using a "set speed" block with the new "speed" parameter to help Penguin get both flags before the other sprites even get one.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 7_instruction:
Let's have some fun! Look at the code provided to see if you can figure out what each block does.
When you're done, use the arrow keys to control Dog and collect all of the flags. NOTE: You don't need to make any changes to the program
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 8_instruction: Use the when actor touches block to send Dog back to the top-left ONLY if Dog touches any of the other actors.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Params 9_instruction:
Here's our game from an earlier stage, but most of the code is hidden. Thereâ€™s a new function score_points.

Edit the function so that a new parameter called points can be added to player_score.

The variable player_score should increase each time Dog tags Cat with pie, and decrease each time that Cat tags Dog with a sandwich.

Note: When you're done, click "Run" to play. When Dog scores 6 points, you will move on to the next puzzle.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars 1_instruction: This time you don't have to write any code, just hit "Run" to play the game! In this game, you're the dog who is trying to collect more flags than the cat. Use the down arrow to control the dog. Press "Finish" when you're done playing.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars 2_instruction: The race in that last puzzle wasn't very fair! Change the dog_speed variable to make sure you can collect more flags than Cat. The first to collect 10 flags wins!
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars 3_instruction: Use the left and right arrows to move, and the up arrow to jump. See if you can collect all of the flags.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars 4_instruction: Now we're using a variable called "height" to control how high the dog can jump. Update the "height" variable so that the dog can jump high enough to reach all the flags.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars 5_instruction: Let's build a game! First we'll need a score. Rebuild the code that you saw in the last level to set the score to 10.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars 6 (copy 1)_instru: Cool, now we've got our score variable, but how are we going to make it useful? How about adding to your score variable each time you hit the enemy with a fireball? Use the "when actor 2 touches anything" event to trigger an update to your score when your fireballs hit the cat. You can increment the score by setting score = score + 1. Get your score up to 10 (going one at a time!) to pass the level.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars 6_instruction:
Use the right arrow to throw pie.

In our game, how should we score points? Add 1 to your "points" variable each time Dog hits Cat with a piece of pie. Use the "when actor 2 touches anything" event to trigger an update to your score. You can increment your variable by setting "points = points + 1." Get your score up to 10 (going one at a time!) to pass the level.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars 7_instruction: Nice, now let's make sure this game isn't too easy to play. Any time Dog (actor 1) gets hit by a sandwich from Cat (actor 2), you should lose a point. Start with 10 points so it's not too hard. Let your score drop down from 10 to 0 to pass the level.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars 8 (copy 1)_instru: Alright, one last thing for this game - let's set it up so the player can win (or lose). Use a forever loop to check the value of score - if score is ever greater that 20, make the enemy vanish. If the score is every less than 0, make the player vanish. Click "Finish" when the game works like you'd like it to.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars 8_instruction: Let's set up this game so the Dog can win (or lose). Use a forever loop to check the value of score - if score is ever greater that 20, make the enemy (the Cat) vanish. If the score is ever less than 0, make the player (the Dog) vanish. Click "Finish" when the game works like you'd like it to.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars 9_instruction:
Free Play time! Here are all of the variables we've played with so far in this stage, as well as a few more in case you want them.

Notice that there are now so many blocks in our toolbox that they need to be organized! Here, we've put each piece into an appropriate category. Take some time to explore everything that is available. When you're done browsing, make a game or story using repeats, variables, and events.

Hint: scroll down to see all the commands in the workspace.
instructions.Course 4 Play Lab Vars_instruction: Alright, one last thing for this game - let's set it up so the player can win (or lose). Use a forever loop to check the value of score - if score is ever greater that 20, make the emeny vanish. If the score is every less than 0, make the player vanish.
instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 1_instructi: Let's make the dog speak every number from 1 to 100. Use a for loop and the counter block to speak the counter variable each time the loop is run.
instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 2_instructi: This time, help Olive the Cat count only the odd numbers from 1 to 101.
instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 3_instructi: If we count by larger numbers, we count even higher in the same amount of time. Try making Pirate Pegleg count from 10 up to 1000, adding 10 at a time.
instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 4_instructi: Changing the increment can be helpful, but we're still counting linearly (each number is the same distance from the last) What if I wanted to count exponentially? Without changing the settings in this for loop, can you count 1, 4, 9 , 16, 25... (counter squared)?
instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 4a_instruct:
Now, let's blend the variables from Stage 7 together with your "counter" variable to make some magic happen.

In this puzzle, Dog will count from 0 to 1000 by "increment". Set the "increment" variable to 10 at the beginning of your code to see what happens.
instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 5_instructi: In the last stage we counted the square of each number. Try changing "counter ^ 2" to "counter ^ 3" to count the cube of each number (1, 8, 27, 64, 125, 216, 343â€¦)
instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 5a_instruct:
In this puzzle, Dog will be your time keeper.

Dog will count from 0 to 30 by "increment". The "increment" variable will begin with a value of 1.

Can you make it so that each time you click Dog, the increment increases by 2? Click the forward arrow to run the for loop.

Run the loop a couple of times, clicking Dog before each one.
instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 6_instructi: You may recall that a prime number is any whole number that is only divisible by itself and 1. Use the "is_prime" function to speak out only the prime numbers from 1 to 100.
instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 6a_instruct:
Dog will still keep time by counting with our "for loop" by "increment", but this time, we will add The Wizard into the mix. Can you change the code so that "increment" goes up by two each time The Wizard is clicked?

Watch out! The Wizard moves quickly!
instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 7_instructi: Could you use a for loop to help me speak the sequence 1, 4, 7, 10, 13, 16, 19, 22, 25?
instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 7a_instruct:
Now we're getting somewhere! What if we start counting how many times we can click The Wizard before Dog gets to 30?

Finish adding blocks to The Wizard so that every time he's clicked the variable "clicked" increases by one. You can ignore "increment" for now.

Dog will start counting when you click "Run".
instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 8_instructi:
Now, help the actors move as they count.

Dog should move and count by adding 2 (counter + 2) each time. Cat will move and count by multiplying by 2 (counter * 2) each time. Penguin will move and count to the power of 2 (counter ^ 2) each time. Who will reach their flag first?
instructions.Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 8a_instruct:
To finish our game, we need to bring back the "increment" variable! Let's tie it to the level of the game.

1) Keep track of the number of times The Wizard is clicked. 2) If The Wizard is clicked at least 10 times before Dog counts to 30, raise "increment" by 1 and start again. 3) If The Wizard does not get clicked at least 10 times, the game is over.
instructions.Course 4 Playlab For Loop Freeplay_instr: Freeplay: Use everything you've learned so far to make a game that includes a for loop!
instructions.Course 4 Playlab For Loops 4b_instructio: Can you change the increment in one of the loops so that the race is a tie?
instructions.Course 4 Playlab For Loops 5b_instructio: Adjust the interval on these for loops so that the two characters end in the exact same place.
instructions.Course 4 Playlab For Loops 6b_instructio: Edit this for loop to create a game that's fun for you to play! Press "Run" and click Madame Unicorn as many times as you can. Can you beat our score of 24?
instructions.Course 4 SCF 1_instruction: Use the suggested functions to draw four rows of hexagons. Notice how our even numbered rows are shifted to the right?
instructions.Course 4 SCF 1a_instruction: Can you figure out how to collect all of this nectar with the fewest blocks possible?
instructions.Course 4 SCF 1b_instruction: Can you figure out how to collect all of this honey with the fewest blocks possible?

instructions.Course 4 SCV 3_instruction:
Now for a game of tag! Tag Cat to get 2 points. Tag Penguin to get 3 points. Get exactly 10 points to win! But be careful, when Cat and Penguin tag each other, they take points away.

Add the blocks necessary to make this game work the way it's been explained. How will you get Dog to move in all directions using the arrow keys? How will you add points when Dog tags Cat or Penguin? How will you subtract points when Cat and Penguin touch?

Use the right arrow to throw pie.

In our game, how should we score points? Add 1 to your "points" variable each time Dog hits Cat with a piece of pie. Use the "when actor 2 touches anything" event to trigger an update to your score. You can increment your variable by setting "points = points + 1." Get your score up to 10 (going one at a time!) to pass the level.
instructions.CourseF_PlayLab_vars9_instruction: Nice, now let's make sure this game isn't too easy to play. Any time Dog (actor 1) gets hit by a sandwich from Cat (actor 2), you should lose a point. Start with 10 points so it's not too hard. Let your score drop down from 10 to 0 to pass the level.

instructions.D_Frozen_nested8_instruction: Spin that shape around 5 or 6 times in a circle.

Try playing around with what you've created. Draw whatever you like!

  • What happens if you use two different angles in your stair step pattern?
  • What happens if you make your diamond pattern longer or shorter?
  • What does it look like to draw two snowflakes on top of one another?

instructions.Eval Booleans 1_instruction: Boolean operators (like >, <, =) allow us to compare different values, returning either true or false. Click "Run" to see how this expression evaluates.
instructions.Eval Booleans 2_instruction: Can you set the values so that this expression evaluates as true?
instructions.Eval Booleans 3_instruction: The string-length function returns the number of characters in a string (including spaces!) - make this code evaluate to true.
instructions.Eval Booleans 4_instruction: Here's an Evaluation Block called AND - it returns true if both of its parameters are true, otherwise it returns false. Edit the x variable so that this expression returns true.
instructions.Eval Booleans 5_instruction: This OR block returns true if either of its parameters is true. Otherwise, if both parameters are false it will return false. Set the y variable to a value that will cause this expression to return false.
instructions.Eval Booleans 6_instruction: Here's one more boolean block called NOT. This block flips true to false, or false to true. If you wrap this block of code in a NOT block, it should return true (because we are asking if the two expressions do NOT produce equal values).
instructions.Eval Booleans Free Play_instruction: Free Play: Try out some creations of your own using Booleans.
instructions.Eval Booleans_instruction: Booleans allow us to compare different values, returning "true" if the are equal, or "false" if they are not. What do you think this code will evaluate to?
instructions.Eval Cond 1_instruction: The cond block checks the boolean expressions in the left column, and as soon as it finds one that returns "true" it runs the corresponding code on the right. If none of the expressions evaluate to "true," it runs the bottom block. Update the "temperature" variable so that this block returns "It's just right."
instructions.Eval Cond 2 (copy 1)_instruction: This condition returns a different shape based on the value of the "sides" variable - change the value of "sides" so that the conditional returns a triangle.
instructions.Eval Cond 2_instruction: This condition returns a different shape based on the value of the "sides" variable - change the value of "sides" so that the conditional returns a triangle.
instructions.Eval Cond 3 (copy 1)_instruction: Can you write a conditional that checks the variable "age" and returns "Old enough to vote and drive" if age > 17, "Old enough to drive" if age is > 15, and "Can't drive or vote" if neither conditions is true. Hint: The first condition to return "true" wins - make sure you put your conditions in the right order.
instructions.Eval Cond 3_instruction: Can you write a conditional that checks the variable "age" and returns "Old enough to vote and drive" if age > 17, "Old enough to drive" if age is > 15, and "Can't drive or vote" if neither conditions is true. Hint: The first condition to return "true" wins - make sure you put your conditions in the right order.
instructions.Eval Cond 4_instruction: We can use the string=? function to make conditionals that respond to text input. Here's a function called green shape that takes a string for the type of shape. Complete the conditions so that the correct solid green shape is returned when the function is run with "circle", "triangle", "square", or "rectangle".
instructions.Eval Cond 5_instruction: Here's a similar function red shape with an additional variable for size. Complete the conditionals so the correct solid red image of a given size is drawn for "circle", "triangle", and "star".
instructions.Eval Cond 6_instruction: Write a function called food-critic, which takes in the name of a food and produces a String that says how you feel about that food. For example, (food-critic â€œpizzaâ€) might evaluate to â€œdeliciousâ€, but (food-critic â€œrotten eggsâ€) might evaluate to â€œgross!â€. Choose at least two foods to review, but you can you write more if you like! Donâ€™t forget to add an â€œelseâ€ clause! One example - and part of the definition - has already been done for you!
instructions.Eval Cond 7_instruction: Free Play: Write a function called green-shape, which takes in the name of a shape and produces a solid green shape. Your function should work with at least â€œcircleâ€, â€œstarâ€ and â€œrectangleâ€, but you can add other shapes if you like. You can choose the size of each shape. Donâ€™t forget to add an â€œelseâ€ clause! One example - and part of the definition - has already been done for you!
instructions.Eval Cond 8_instruction: Free Play: Suppose you want to own a car at 21, or have your own business by 30. Write a function called life-goals, which takes in an age and produces a string that describes your life goals by then. Donâ€™t forget to add an â€œelseâ€ clause!
instructions.Eval Contracts 1_instruction: Use the "star" function to produce a red star with a 60 pixel radius
instructions.Eval Contracts 10A_instruction: Alright let's complete this puzzle with a Green Square that is 175 pixels in size.
instructions.Eval Contracts 11A_instruction: Can you complete this puzzle to read "Hello World" in the banner?
instructions.Eval Contracts 2_instruction: Check out the "rotate" function - can you use it to rotate this 90 pixel green square by 45 degrees?
instructions.Eval Contracts 3_instruction: Try using the "text" function to write this teal text at size 40.
instructions.Eval Contracts 4 A_instruction: The "scale" function returns an image that is scaled either larger or smaller than the input image. Try scaling this circle by a factor of 10 - how is the resulting image different than if you'd just made a circle of that size in the first place?
instructions.Eval Contracts 4_instruction: The scale function returns an image that is either larger or smaller than the input image. Try scaling this circle by a factor of 10. How is the returned image different than if you'd just made a circle of that size in the first place?
instructions.Eval Contracts 8A_instruction: Can you complete this puzzle? The big-triangle is 200 pixels in size and purple?
instructions.Eval Contracts A_instruction: Use the star function to produce a solid red star with a 60 pixel radius
instructions.Eval Contracts C_instruction: Check out the rotate function - can you use it to rotate this 90 pixel green square by 45 degrees?
instructions.Eval Contracts E_instruction: Try using the text function to write "Hello, world!" in teal at size 40.
instructions.Eval Contracts shrink_instruction: Can you complete this image using the "shrink" function block? The radius is 20.
instructions.Eval Define Funcs 1_instruction: Here's a new function called green-triangle that takes a single Number for size and produces a green triangle. Use the new function to create a 125 pixel green triangle.
instructions.Eval Define Funcs 2_instruction: Let's look inside that green-triangle function to see how it works. Can you modify it so that the green-triangle function always draws outlined green triangles?
instructions.Eval Define Funcs 3_instruction: Here's the start of another new function called purple-circle with a domain of one Number (the radius) and a range of Image. The body of the function is broken though - fix it and then make a purple circle with 150 pixel radius
instructions.Eval Define Funcs 4_instruction: Create a new function called aqua-star that has a Domain of a single Number for radius and returns an aqua star of the given radius. Run your new function with a radius of 75.
instructions.Eval Define Funcs 5_instruction: Let's use that aqua-star function to make a row of different sized stars. From left to right, the stars should have radii of 25, 50, and 75.
instructions.Eval Define Funcs Test_instruction: Here's the start of another new function called purple-circle with a domain of one Number (the radius) and a range of Image. The body of the function is broken though - fix it and then make a purple circle with 150 pixel radius
instructions.Eval Defining Vars Free Play 1_instructi: Free Play: We've provided a function that fills your screen with my-image. Change my-image to see what patterns you can make.
instructions.Eval Design Recipe .1_instruction: Here's a Design Recipe for a function called square-circle with domain Number String and range Image. Click Edit to write the function definition (you will see two examples provided).
instructions.Eval Design Recipe 1 (copy 1)_instructio: We're going to write a function that draws a solid rectangle of any color that is twice wide as it is high. Start with an example - draw a solid green rectangle that has a height on 100 pixels.
instructions.Eval Design Recipe 1_instruction: Alright, now given the Contract wide-rect: Number String -> Image, write an example - draw a solid green rectangle that has a height of 100 pixels.
instructions.Eval Design Recipe 2 (copy 1)_instructio: Let's do one more example before writing the function definition - this time draw a solid red rectangle with a height of 75 pixels.
instructions.Eval Design Recipe 2_instruction: Let's do one more example before writing the function definition - this time draw a solid red rectangle with a height of 75 pixels.
instructions.Eval Design Recipe 3_instruction: The Design Recipe for wide-rect already has a contract and one example. Can you write a second example and then complete the definition? The wide-rect function should produce a rectangle of given color that is twice as wide as it is high.
instructions.Eval Design Recipe 4_instruction: Use the Design Recipe to create a function starburst. When given a number of points and an outer radius, starburst returns a yellow radial star with given points, and an inner radius that is half the outer radius.
instructions.Eval Design Recipe 5_instruction: Using the Design Recipe, write a function striped-flag that takes two colors and produces a flag that is 250 pixels wide, 150 pixels tall, with three even horizontal stripes of given colors, in the order color2, color1, color2.
instructions.Eval Design Recipe 6_instruction: Write a function large-polygon that should output a solid polygon of given sides and color that takes up most of the window, regardless of the number of sides. To make sure that the polygon doesn't get too large as you increase the number of sides, side length should be inversely proportional to side number, with a length of (800/sides).
instructions.Eval Design Recipe Free Play_instruction: Free Play: Use the Design Recipe to create some functions of your own design
instructions.Eval Strings Images .1_instruction: So far we've only dealt with a single type of data, Numbers. Another type of data is a String, which is any combination of letters, numbers, or other characters wrapped in quotation marks. Run the String "Hello, world!" and see what happens.
instructions.Eval Strings Images .2_instruction: The string-append function takes two Strings and returns a single combined String. Add a String "Universe" to the second argument of string-append.
instructions.Eval Strings Images 1_instruction: The third type of data we're going to use is an Image. This star function takes in a Number and two Strings, and it evaluates to an Image. Use this function to make a solid red star with radius of 100.
instructions.Eval Strings Images 2_instruction: Free Play: Every Evaluation Block is color-coded to let you know which data type it returns and which types it needs for its parameters. The last parameter of the triangle function takes a String that controls its color - try some different colors to see what works.
instructions.Eval Strings Images 3_instruction: Some functions can only take a specific set of Strings, such as the second argument of this circle function, which controls its style. Draw this orange outline circle using the special String block with a dropdown to make sure you only use valid styles.
instructions.Eval Strings Images 4_instruction: Try using the rectangle block to draw this solid, red rectangle - it is 175 pixels wide and 100 pixels tall.
instructions.Eval Strings Images 5_instruction: Try using this new Evaluation Block called overlay to place a 100 pixel white triangle on top of a 200 pixel red circle.
instructions.Eval Strings Images 6_instruction: Use the overlay block to place a 75 pixel radius yellow star on top of a 150 pixel long blue square.
instructions.Eval Strings Images 7_instruction: The offset block lets you move an image relative to where it would normally be placed. Use this block to offset the square by 100 pixels on the y-axis.
instructions.Eval Strings Images 8_instruction: Here's a different kind of star block - it's called radial-star and it allows you to draw stars with any number of points! Use it to create a 7 point solid orange star with an inner radius of 75 pixels and an outer radius of 175 pixels.
instructions.Eval Strings Images Free Play_instructio: Free Play: Explore the blocks available to create something interesting. Make sure to share your favorite creations.

instructions.Luigi's Pizza 1_instruction: Welcome to Luigi's Pizza! To order a pizza, type the name of a topping into the cost function, and we'll return the price of that pizza. Try ordering a pepperoni pizza to start.
instructions.Luigi's Pizza 2 (copy 1)_instruction: Right now there are only four choices available at Luigi's pizza - let's fix that! Add a couple of new toppings to the conditional block in the "cost" function. Once you've added your toppings, test out the function to make sure it works.
instructions.Luigi's Pizza 2_instruction: Right now there are only four choices available at Luigi's pizza - let's fix that! Add a couple of new toppings to the conditional block in the cost function. Once you've added your toppings, test out the function to make sure it works.
instructions.Luigi's Pizza 3 (copy 1)_instruction: That's better, everyone loves more variety in their pizza toppings! But you still can't please everyone, and folks are coming in to order toppings that Luigi doesn't have. Instead of saying no to those people, could you update the "else" clause so that we charge them a premium for toppings that we don't normally offer?
instructions.Luigi's Pizza 3_instruction: That's better, everyone loves more variety in their pizza toppings! But you still can't please everyone, and folks are coming in to order toppings that Luigi doesn't have. Instead of saying no to those people, could you update the else clause so that we charge them a premium for toppings that we don't normally offer? Let's charge $10,000 for a topping we don't carry.
instructions.Luigi's Pizza 4_instruction: Free Play: What can you do to make Luigi's cost function even more useful?
instructions.MC Agent Freeplay_instruction: Freeplay: Time to explore on your own!
instructions.MC HOC 2016 Level 10_instruction: It's time to make your own Minecraft! Spawn creatures and then make them do whatever you want. Have fun!
instructions.MC HOC 2016 Level 2-2_instruction: The chicken is frozen. Place move and turn blocks in the when spawned slot to get it to move.
instructions.MC HOC 2016 Level 3_instruction: Great, the chicken moved! But then she stopped. In games, chickens walk forever. Use a forever do loop to keep these chickens moving.
instructions.MC HOC 2016 Level 4_instruction: Now the chickens look weird moving the same way. Games use random moves to make things look real. Make the chickens turn random.
instructions.MC HOC 2016 Level 5_instruction: These cows are lost! Lead them to the grass with the move a step toward block in a forever do loop.
instructions.MC HOC 2016 Level 6_instruction: Now you make the zombies. Use the spawn block to make 3 zombies when night falls. Get them to move towards you. Survive until morning.
instructions.MC HOC 2016 Level 8_instruction: The path to your sheep is blocked by a stone wall. Luckily there is a Creeper here. Creepers explode after you touch them. Get the Creeper to explode the wall so you can reach your sheep!
instructions.MC HOC 2016 New Drop_instruction: In Minecraft, sheep drop wool. Place the drop block in when used, then walk over and use the sheep to drop an item.
instructions.MC HOC 2016 New Spawn_instruction: Now you can fill the world with what you want! Placespawn blocks under when run to spawn things when the game starts.
instructions.MC HOC 2016 New Walk_instruction: Let's explore our world! Move with the arrows, and press the space bar or tap the game board to use items. Use the door to get inside the house.
instructions.MC HOC 2016 SCORE LEVEL_instruction: Some games let you keep score. Play tag with these Iron Golems and use the add 1 to score block to give yourself a point when you tag them. Reach five points to win!
instructions.MC HOC 2016 Village Test_instruction: Oh no! Zombies have trapped you inside! Code the Iron Golem to chase and attack the zombies!

instructions.MSM Big Game Empty_instruction: All variables and functions are currently empty stubs. Each puzzle progression will be focused on defining and handful of them, and therefore adding functionality.

instructions.MSM Defining Vars 1 (copy 1)_instruction: Write a program that produces a 50 pixel solid green triangle.
instructions.MSM Defining Vars 1_instruction: Write a program that produces a 50 pixel solid green triangle.
instructions.MSM Defining Vars 2 (copy 1)_instruction: If we wanted to make fifty green triangles, it would be a pain to repeat that block of code 50 times. Let's create a variable called "my-shape" and put the code for a 50 pixel solid green triangle inside.
instructions.MSM Defining Vars 2_instruction: If we wanted to make fifty green triangles, it would be a pain to repeat that block of code 50 times. Let's create a variable called my-shape and put the code for a 50 pixel solid green triangle inside.
instructions.MSM Defining Vars 3 (copy 1)_instruction: Take your "my-shape" variable and use it with this provided code to draw two identical green triangles.
instructions.MSM Defining Vars 3_instruction: Take your my-shape variable and use it with this provided code to draw two identical green triangles that are 50 pixels in size.
instructions.MSM Defining Vars 4_instruction: Edit your my-shape variable so that it draws 75 pixel solid red stars.
instructions.MSM Play Lab Butterfly 1_instruction: Help Sam stay on the screen so that you can always see at least a little piece of him. Using the arrow keys, see how far Sam can go to the left while still staying onscreen. Youâ€™ll find that Sam is onscreen as long as his x-coordinate is greater than -50. Then, fill in the code to make Sam stay on the screen.
instructions.MSM Play Lab Butterfly 2_instruction: Now make Sam stay on the right side of the screen. You'll have to experiment to see how far he can go and still be partially visible on the screen.
instructions.MSM Play Lab Butterfly 3_instruction: Now, combine your work to make Sam stay on both sides of the screen.
instructions.MSM Play Lab Game 2_instruction: Variables can also be used to control the speed of players in a game. Set the player speed and the enemy speed and see how the movement changes. Speed can be between 2 and 12.
instructions.Mike Test Bee Conditionals 1_instruction: This cloud is blocking my view! Check to see if there's a flower under the cloud, and only get nectar if there's a flower. Be careful, it can change!
instructions.Mike Test Bee Conditionals 2_instruction: Collect all of the nectar. You can only collect nectar from flowers, but you can check any space to see if there is a flower.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 1_instruct: Can you draw a square that is 100 pixels in length, using a repeat loop?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 10.1_instr: Use the functions from the previous puzzles to draw this pattern.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 10_instruc: Click "edit" to fill out the blocks in the function definition to make a 40 pixel square.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 11_instruc: Now we want to create a new function called draw a line of squares that draws six squares all in a row. Can you build this function using this draw a square 20 function that we created for you?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 12_instruc: Use the draw a line of squares function from the last puzzle to draw this pattern.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 13_instruc: Can you draw a star shape using the draw a line of squares function?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 2_instruct: Can you draw 3 squares 20 pixels apart from one another? Each square is 100 pixels in size.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 3_instruct:
Here is a new type of Block. It is called a function block. Click "edit" then fill it with the code for drawing a square with 100 pixel sides.

When you're done editing the function, click "Close" to go back to your program.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 4_instruct: Use the draw a square function to draw this pattern.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 5_instruct: How did the "draw a square" block know what commands to run? Click on "edit" in the "draw a square" function block. The blocks in the function editor are the definition that make up "draw a square." When you're done looking around, click "Save and Close" and then "Run."
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 6_instruct: Using the "draw a square" function block, can you draw this picture? Hint: each square is 20 pixels apart.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 7_instruct: Are you getting the hang of how to use function blocks? Let's modify this square so that it is 200 pixels in size. Click on "edit" to enter the draw a square function editor. Remember to click on "Close" to get out of the function editor.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 8_instruct: We have created a new function for you called "draw a triangle". Can you edit the function definition to draw a triangle with 100 pixel sides?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions 9_instruct: Can you solve this by adding only one block?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Functions inspire_in: Click here to see the inspiration picture again.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 1_instruction: Let's define this function to draw a square with 50 pixel sides. Click "edit" to get started.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 10_instructio: Create a draw a hexagon function block with a length parameter. This hexagon has sides that are 100 pixels in length.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 11_instructio: Can you figure out how to draw this shape? Edit the function to use the "sides" parameter.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 12_instructio: Can you complete this drawing? The sides of all the shapes are 100 pixels long.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 12a_instructi: This image is similar to the last. Can you use a for loop with your function to make this design?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 13_instructio: Let's edit this "draw a polygon" function. It already has a "sides" parameter. Now, let's add a "length" parameter. The perimeter of each shape is 200 pixels long. Do you remember the equation to make shapes the same size when they have a different number of sides?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 14_instructio: Edit "draw a spiral edge" to use "length" and "sides" parameters, then recreate these shapes.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 15_instructio: Freeplay: Here are the functions you've written, and some more for you to play with. Draw something awesome! Play with the pen width to see how different your drawings look!
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 2_instruction: Create a draw triangle function from scratch that makes a triangle with 50 pixel sides.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 3_instruction: Now let's use the function to draw 5 triangles in a row. Each triangle is 30 pixels apart.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 4_instruction: Do you notice anything different about these function blocks? Click â€œRunâ€ to see what happens.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 5_instruction: Replace the ??? in the length parameter input block. The pentagon has 100 pixel sides.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 6_instruction: Fill in the "length" parameter to draw these shapes by replacing the "???" with the right numbers. The square and triangle have 100 pixels sides while each side of the hexagon is 75 pixels long.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 7_instruction: Can you complete this drawing? The sides of each triangle are 25 pixels larger than the last. The first triangle has 25 pixel sides.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 8_instruction: The code for this triangle function is broken. Can you edit the function to fix it, and then make triangles of length 25, 50, and 75?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params 9_instruction: Click "edit" to fill in the function definition of "draw a square" and add a parameter. It should take a length parameter, just like the triangle. This time, draw 3 squares: 25, 50 and 75 pixels in length, each 100 pixels apart.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Params inspire_instr:
Free Play Inspiration: You've now learned everything you need to know to make a pattern like this! If this picture inspires you, try to make something similar. Otherwise, create something all your own.

Want to know how our inspiration pattern was made?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Vars 1.5_instruction: Take a look at the code, can you see how the "set length" block and "length" block works together? Click on "Run" to see it in action.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Vars 12_instruction: Now, recreate the algorithm from the last level and create a pentagon with sides of length 150.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Vars 2.5_instruction: Take a look at the code, can you see how the "set length" block and "length" block works together? Click on "Run" to see it in action.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Vars 2_instruction: Drag a number block to both the set length block and the repeat _ times block to draw a set of 50 pixel triangles.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Vars 4 5_instruction: Awesome job on the last puzzle, let's try it again this time let's make this cool design with with 60 pixel hexagon's.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Vars 4_instruction:
Let's try it again!

Can you set the length variable to 60 to make this cool design with hexagons?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Artist Vars 6_instruction:
Draw this pattern of pentagons with 100 pixel sides by setting the right value for length and dropping the length variable into all of the the correct places.

See how you only have to set the value for length once, and the code uses the right value everywhere?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 1_instruction: Use a loop to collect the nectar from each flower.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 10_instructio: Use your for loop "counter" variable to control how far to move horizontally.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 10a_instructi: Ready for a challenge? Take what you've learned about loops and try to solve this problem. Remember: You may have to run through solutions multiple times before you figure out all of the steps.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 11_instructio: Can you use the loop variable to control movement and nectar collection?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 2_instruction: Add the code necessary to make sure the bee collects all the nectar. Look at how much code you need for this puzzle! (We'll learn a simpler way in the next puzzle.)
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 3_instruction: Ah, the "for loop" makes this much easier! All the code you need is here, take a look at how it is put together then click "Run" to see how it works.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 4 4_instructi: Now we need to move forward "counter" times, then get nectar "counter" times. Can you use two "repeat" loops to solve this challenge?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 4_instruction: Replace the ??? in the "for loop" with the largest amount of nectar the bee has to collect.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 5 5_instructi: Are you getting the hang of using the "for loop"? Let's help the bee get the rest of the nectar.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 5_instruction: You can also use a "for loop" to count down. Try gathering this nectar by counting down from 5 to 1 by 1.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 6_instruction: The last number in your for loop is called the "increment". Each time the loop is run, the counter variable changes by the value of the increment. Try collecting these flowers using an increment of 2.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 7_instruction:
Now, let's combine the "counter" variable with a math block! How can you use the "counter" variable to navigate this garden with the fewest number of blocks possible? What do you need to do to collect 3, 6, 9, 12, 15 nectar this time? The secret is in the "counter" variable!

Remember: If your loop is counting up, the increment is added to your "counter" variable each time through.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 8_instruction: You've got this! What should your increment be to collect 3, 6, 9, 12, 15 nectar?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 9_instruction: If your loop is counting down, the increment is subtracted from your counter variable each loop. What should your increment be to collect 15, then 12, then 9, 6, 3 nectar?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Bee For Loops 95_instructio: Take a look at each piece of the "for loop" that you have just created. Can you figure out which numbers you need to double to solve this puzzle? Why does it work?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Play Lab Params 11_instruct: It's free play time! Have fun with all the blocks in your tool box.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Play Lab Params 5 5_instruc: Let's try that again, but with less help. What do you need to edit this time to make the actors patrol?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Play Lab Vars 4 5_instructi: â€œWhat do you think this code will do? Press â€œRunâ€ to see what happens.â€
instructions.NEW Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 7a_inst: Using what you learned so far, can you have Dinosaur take a step forward every time Penguin counts?
instructions.NEW Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 8 Free: It's Free Play time, have fun with all the blocks in your tool box.
instructions.NEW Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 8a_inst: Challenge: How would you use the "for loop" to get every actor to go around and say their actor number, then vanish from the screen?
instructions.NetSim Standalone Automatic DNS_instruct: In this version of the Internet Simulator, a Domain Name System (DNS) is provided for you and knows the IP addresses of all connected computers. Send a message in the form GET [hostname] to the DNS service at address .15 to get a student's address.
instructions.NetSim Standalone Broadcast_instruction: In this version of the Internet Simulator, you can connect to up to 5 other people in a room. When you send messages in the room, everyone receives them. What are some of the challenges of this system, and how might you solve them?
instructions.NetSim Standalone Classroom Routers_inst: In this version of the Internet Simulator, everyone connects to a router and has a specific address. To send messages, you have to address your message to the specific address of the recipient, and the router will take care of delivering it to the right computer. If there are other routers created in your class, ask for the address of one of your classmates and send them a message! View the Log Router to see the path the messages have taken through the network.
instructions.NetSim Standalone Freeplay_instruction: In this configuration, most of the options are turned on, and you can play with them. Have fun!
instructions.NetSim Standalone Manual DNS_instruction: In this version of the simulator you can't see the other students' addresses. Instead, one of you must act as a name service, to help share addresses with each other.
instructions.NetSim Standalone Packets TCP_instructio: Messages on the Internet can take many paths to get to their destination, and sometimes along the way the message gets dropped. In this version of the Internet Simulator, there is a 10% chance of a packet being dropped, multiple packets may take different paths to the destination, and the default max packet size is set to 6 additional characters.
instructions.NetSim Standalone Routers Addresses_inst:
For this activity, connect to a router with the others in your group. Important note: The router will only properly route messages where the first 4 bits are the To: address and the second 4 bits are the From: address.

[TODO: NetSim needs to support hierarchical addresses. For now, level is set up for 4 bit to and from addresses]
instructions.NetSim Standalone SendAB_instruction: You and your partner share a single wire that can only be in state A or state B. You can set the wire to either state at any time, and you can read the state of the wire at any time. Can you figure out a way to effectively communicate with just this system?
instructions.NetSim Standalone Sending Numbers Ascii_: Now that you've transmitted information represented as decimal numbers, you can map those numbers to text characters to send text-based information back and forth. With a text-based protocol, you can easily represent and communicate all kinds of information.
instructions.NetSim Standalone Sending Numbers_instru: You and your partner can now reliably send messages back and forth without extra coordination! While you're always sending bits back and forth, you can also represent those bits as decimal numbers. What kinds of information can you represent with this system?
instructions.NetSim_AddressingMessages_instruction: In this version of the simulator, you will connect to a Router instead of directly to another student. Enter an address in the "To" box to send a message to another student.
instructions.NetSim_AutomaticDNS_instruction: In this version of the simulator a DNS service is provided for you. Send a message in the form GET [hostname] to the DNS service at address 15 to get a student's address.
instructions.NetSim_ManualDNS_instruction: In this version of the simulator you can't see the other students' addresses. Instead, one of you must act as a name service, to help share addresses with each other.
instructions.NetSim_SendAB_instruction: Connect to another student. Each of you can set the value of the wire between you to "A" or "B". See if you can send a complete message!
instructions.NetSim_SendAscii_instruction: In this version of the simulator, you can send numbers or ASCII characters to one another, one bit at a time.
instructions.NetSim_SendBits_instruction: Connect to another student. You can now set your wire to "0" or "1". Send a message to your partner!
instructions.NetSim_SendNumbers_instruction: In this version of the simulator, you can view the decimal representations of the binary you are sending.
instructions.NetSim_SendingABTest_instruction: This is Sarah's test of making a netsim level
instructions.NetSim_Superuser_instruction: You have loaded NetSim in superuser mode.
instructions.NetSim_Variant1_instruction: NetSim: Variant 1 allows students to manually work out the timing of sending bits back and forth.
instructions.NetSim_Variant2_instruction: NetSim: Variant 2: Students connect directly to one another and send entire packets back and forth, exploring systems of encoding data.
instructions.NetSim_Variant3_instruction: NetSim: Variant 3: Connects groups of 2-6 students with a router, and explores issues in routing and DNS
instructions.New Artist Project_instruction: Draw something awesome! Your code is saved as a project that you can return to at any time.
instructions.New Basketball Project_instruction: Create your own Basketball game. You can change all the rules. When you're done, click Finish to let friends try your game on their phones.
instructions.New Bounce Project_instruction: Create your own Bounce game. You can change all the visuals and the rules. When you're done, click Finish to let friends try your game on their phones.

instructions.New Sports Project_instruction: Create your own game! You're in charge here: you can change all the rules, mix and match sports, get creative! When you're done, click Finish to let friends try your game on their phones.

instructions.PDAlg 13-16 Sam Extension Puzzle_instruc: Add a second parameter to "onscreen?" for Sam's y coordinate and update the function so it keeps him safe on all four sides.
instructions.PDAlg 17-20 Luigi Extension Puzzle_instr: Without modifying your existing "cost" function, create a new "coupon" function that takes a pizza topping and coupon code and returns the cost of a pizza with that topping. If the coupon code is correct (you get to decide what it is), apply a 30% discount to the pizza.
instructions.PDAlg 8-12 Rocket Height Puzzle_instruct: Let's write a "rocket-height" function with simple acceleration. Write a function that ensures the rocket is at 15 meters at 1 second, 45 meters at 2 seconds, 95 at 3 seconds, and 165 at 4 seconds.
instructions.PDAlg 8-12 ex dr 1_instruction: The definition in this Design Recipe doesn't match both examples. Test each example to see which is failing, and then fix the definition to match.
instructions.PDAlg 8-12 ex dr 2_instruction: This student has created two examples for the function "apples" but something's not quite right. How would you direct this student to correct their mistake?
instructions.PDAlg Big Game History_instruction: Now that you've played through a Big Game level you should see a new entry in your history. Click the Version History button and you should see at least one version. Each time you go back to a Big Game level you'll get a new record in your version history that you can revert back to.
instructions.PDAlg Big Game Remix_instruction:
Here's your Big Game as you last left it. Try clicking the Remix button to spin off a new remix of your project.

Any changes you make after you click Remix will be saved on your new remix and not on your main Big Game.
instructions.PDAlg Design Recipe Delete_instruction: Click the delete button to get rid of this function, then try creating and deleting a few of your own.
instructions.PDAlg Design Recipe Examples_instruction: The definition in this Design Recipe doesn't match both examples. Test each example to see which is failing, and then fix the definition to match.
instructions.PDAlg Design Recipe Required_instruction: Complete the Design Recipe for the "eggs" function, making sure to create and test your examples.
instructions.PDAlg Updates Cond_instruction: When you went to PD in the summer, the Conditional block that you were introduced to was black and allowed any data type to be used. This proved to be confusing, given that every other function we've seen always produces the same type of data. To help make conditionals clearer and more consistent we've replaced the single black block with a separate block for each data type.
instructions.PDAlg Updates Errors_instruction: Run the provided program and use the error messages to try and track down the bugs.
instructions.PDAlg Updates Space_instruction: Making use of limited programming space (especially on small screens) is challenging with a block based language. To help with this we've added a few features. Experiment with this provided code to see how the space can be manipulated to deal with larger programs.
instructions.PDK5 Conditionals 1_instruction: Purple flowers may have either 1 or 0 nectar, but you don't know which one! Be careful not to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any. Check if the nectar is equal to 1 by using the if block.
instructions.PDK5 Conditionals 2_instruction: Try this puzzle that uses conditionals and loops together. Use the "if" block to decide when to turn. Hint: you only need one more block to complete this puzzle.
instructions.PDK5 Events 1_instruction: So far all of the programs we've written are executed in order from top to bottom. In this puzzle, we'll use "Events" to respond to an action on demand. Make the octopus say "Hello" only when you click on the Octopus.
instructions.PDK5 Functions 1_instruction: Hello. Me zombie artist. Me love drawing! Help me draw the square glasses. Hint: the bridge between the glasses is 25 pixels shorter than the square length.
instructions.PDK5 Functions 2_instruction: Functions let you define new blocks! We've moved the blocks to draw a square into a function called "draw a square". Can you use the "draw a square" function to create the glasses? The squares are 75 pixels apart.
instructions.PDK5 Loops 1_instruction: Instead of using 5 "move forward" blocks, use the "repeat" block with a "move forward" block inside of it. In computer science, this is called a "loop."
instructions.PDK5 Loops 3_instruction: Here's another puzzle to practice loops. What happens if you use the repeat block to run the code already provided on the workspace 4 times?
instructions.PS - test - pixelation_instruction: Complete the X shape by typing 0s and 1s
instructions.PS FR test 7-25_instruction: Here are your instructions for this free response.
instructions.PS Log test - Define and use turnAround_: Define a function called turnAround. Call the function and then move the turtle forward. (Click to see full instructions)
instructions.PS copy 2-3 Bee Conditionals 5_instructi: Be careful not to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any. You must first check if the nectar is equal to 1 using the if nectar block.
instructions.Pattern Bee 1_instruction: What a strange field of goodies! I wonder if there's a pattern here...
instructions.Pixelation - AllTheThings 4_instruction: This pixelation level demonstrates the use of the hide_encoding_controls option. Notice that the level displays the image data in hexadecimal and does not let you change it back to binary.
instructions.Pixelation - AllTheThings 5_instruction: This pixelation level demonstrates the use of the "Hide sliders" option. Notice that the width and height sliders are not available, and the width and height fields are not editable.
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 14 - Fix bit offset: Something happened to the bits in this image! Find the error and fix it! Hint: a few extra bits were added. You should only need to remove some bits.
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 14 - Fix bit offset_: A single extra bit was inserted into the stream of bits that make up the C of the Code.org logo. That extra bit bumps all of the other bits down the line which makes the logo look messed up. Hunt down the extra bit and remove it to fix the Code.org logo.

A single extra bit was inserted into the stream of bits that make up the C of the Code.org logo. That extra bit bumps all of the other bits down the line which makes the logo look messed up. Hunt down the extra bit and remove it to fix the Code.org logo.
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 14 - Fix the error_i: Something happened to the bits in this image! Find error and fix it! Hint: a few extra bits were added. You should only need to remove some bits.
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 14 - Make the Letter: Make a 3x5 letter 'A'. The widget is setup with the incorrect dimensions. Your first task is to set the second byte to the 8-bit binary code for 5: 0000 0101. Then start entering pixel data.
Make a 3x5 letter 'A'. The widget is setup with the incorrect dimensions. Your first task is to set the second byte to the 8-bit binary code for 5: 0000 0101. Then start entering pixel data.
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 14 - Make your own B: Now make your own image! We've started you off with a 10x10 canvas but you can make it whatever size you want. Happy pixeling!
Now make your own image! We've started you off with a 10x10 canvas but you can make it whatever size you want. Happy pixeling!
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 15 - Color Free Play: Requirements: The icon must be 16x16 pixels. You must use the Pixelation Widget to encode the bits of color information. The image must be encoded with at least 12 bits per pixel.
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 15 - Color Shades 4x: We start you out with the 4x4 image Maddie created in the video. Your task is to fill a 4x4 grid with colors using 12-bits per pixel. Here are the requirements: Row 1 - fill with shades of red. Row 2 - shades of green. Row 3 - shades of blue. Row 4 - shades of gray.

We start you out with the 4x4 image Maddie created in the video. Your task is to fill a 4x4 grid with colors using 12-bits per pixel. Here are the requirements: Row 1 - fill with shades of red. Row 2 - shades of green. Row 3 - shades of blue. Row 4 - shades of gray.
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 15 - Color Shades_in: We start you out with the row of shades of red that Maddie created in the video. Experiment with 6-bit color by filling in the bottom row of the image with shades of a different color. Here is an example with some shades of blue. Try your own color!
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 15 - Color Shades_20: We start you out with the row of shades of red that Maddie created in the video. Experiment with 6-bit color by filling in the bottom row of the image with shades of a different color. Here is an example with some shades of blue. Try your own color!
instructions.Pixelation - Lesson 15 - Complete 3-bit: We start you with the 4x2 image Maddie was creating, but we've left out the last two squares. Finish off the image by figuring out which two colors are missing and encode them.
We start you with the 4x2 image Maddie was creating, but we've left out the last two squares. Finish off the image by figuring out which two colors are missing and encode them.
instructions.Pixelation 2_instruction: Something happened to the bits in this image! Find error and fix it!
instructions.Pixelation 4x4 Empty_instruction: The width and height are now encoded in the pixel data. Can you figure out how to adjust the dimensions?
instructions.Pixelation Bee_instruction: This larger image of a bee encodes color with 12 bits per pixel, but viewing in hex makes it easier to see the color of each pixel. If you switch to binary mode - hold on to your hat - it's a lot of bits. Here's another mind-blowing thing to try: slide the bits per pixel up to 24 bits per pixel. What happens? Can you explain this behavior?
instructions.Pixelation Bee_2018_instruction: This larger image of a bee encodes color with 12 bits per pixel, but viewing in hex makes it easier to see the color of each pixel. If you switch to binary mode - hold on to your hat - it's a lot of bits. Here's another mind-blowing thing to try: slide the bits per pixel up to 24 bits per pixel. What happens? Can you explain this behavior?
instructions.Pixelation Flappy_instruction: Here is a bigger image at 9 bits per pixel. With 9 bits per pixel you can express 512 different colors. Click through to see the next image which is even more sophisticated, but easier to understand.
instructions.Pixelation Flappy_2018_instruction: Here is a bigger image at 9 bits per pixel. With 9 bits per pixel you can express 512 different colors. Click through to see the next image which is even more sophisticated, but easier to understand.
instructions.Pizza on a Plate_instruction: Project Idea: Create a picture of something familiar from the real world. This requires persistence and planning!
instructions.Planning Farmer_instruction: What a strange field of goodies! I wonder if there's a pattern here...
instructions.Play Lab Rocket 1_instruction: A rocket blasts off, traveling at 15 meters per second... press "Run" to see how this word problem looks as an animation.
instructions.Play Lab Rocket 2_instruction: We've started the Design Recipe for rocket-height using the contract and examples you just wrote. Complete the function definition for rocket-height and run your animation.
instructions.Play Lab Rocket 2B_instruction: A rocket blasts off, traveling at 15 meters per second. Using the Design Recipe, write a function called rocket-height that takes in a number of seconds that have passed since the rocket took off, and produces the height of the rocket at that time.
instructions.Play Lab Rocket 3_instruction: Awesome, now can you update that function so that our rocket moves more quickly? Make sure to update the purpose statement, examples, and function definition to launch a rocket at 40 meters per second.
instructions.Play Lab Rocket 4 (copy 1)_instruction: Real rockets start off slowly and gain speed over time - let's make ours do the same! Write an exponential function that describes a rocket that travels at "seconds" squared meters per second.
instructions.Play Lab Rocket 4_instruction: Real rockets start off slowly and gain speed over time - so let's add some simple acceleration to ours! Can you write a function that describes a rocket that is at 10 meters at 1 second, 40 meters at 2 seconds, 90 meters at 3 seconds, 160 at 4 seconds and so on?
instructions.Play Lab Rocket 5_instruction: Much better, but let's write one more function with simple acceleration. This time the rocket should be 15 meters at 1 second, 45 meters at 2 seconds, 95 at 3 seconds, and 165 at 4 seconds.
instructions.Play Lab Rocket Free Play_instruction: Free Play: Experiment with your rocket-height function to make the rocket fly in different ways. Click "Finish" when you are done.
