instructions.Sam the Butterfly 1 (copy 1)_instruction: This butterfly is named Sam, and the game area is Samâ€™s yard. Sam's yard is 400 pixels wide by 400 pixels tall! As you can see, Sam is free to walk around the yard, and the coordinates at the top of the screen update to tell you his location. Use the arrow keys to move sam around his yard. Help Sam collect all of the flags to move on.
instructions.Sam the Butterfly 1_instruction: This bat is named Sam, and the game area is Samâ€™s yard. Sam's yard is 400 pixels wide by 400 pixels tall! As you can see, Sam is free to walk around the yard, and the coordinates at the top of the screen update to tell you his location. Click "Run" and then use the arrow keys to move Sam around his yard, making note of Sam's coordinates at different locations. Click "Finish" when you're ready to move on.
instructions.Sam the Butterfly 2_instruction: Sam's mom wants to make sure that she can always see at least a bit of him, so lets write some functions that help make sure he doesn't go too far out of the yard. Here's a function called safe-left? - it should take a Number for its domain that represents Sam's x-coordinates and return true if he's completely visible on screen. If your function works, Sam shouldn't be able to leave the yard from the left side.
instructions.Sam the Butterfly 3_instruction: In the last puzzle we kept Sam from leaving on the left, now let's do the same thing on the right. Complete the safe-right? function to make sure Sam can't go off the right side of the screen.
instructions.Sam the Butterfly 4_instruction: Huh, we can keep Sam from leaving on the left, or we can keep him from leaving on the right, but how can we keep him safe from leaving both directions? Try using the and block to program the function on-screen? to check if Sam is safe-left? and safe-right?
instructions.Sam the Butterfly 5_instruction: Free Play: Awesome, we've kept Sam safe on the left and right! Use this free play stage to experiment with your functions and further improve onscreen?
instructions.Sam the Butterfly 6_instruction: We've added a new parameter "y" to the "on-screen?" function. Update the function so that it checks that "safe-left?" AND "safe-right?" AND "safe-up?" are all true. When you've fixed the function, try going out of the yard from the left, right, and top sides.
instructions.Sam the Butterfly 7_instruction: Only one last direction to worry about! Create a "safe-down?" function and update the "on-screen?" function so that it checks up, down, left, and right.
instructions.Sam the Butterfly Complete_instruction: Only one last direction to worry about! Create a "safe-down?" function and update the "on-screen?" function so that it checks up, down, left, and right.
instructions.SpecialFrozenLevel_instruction: You've officially become a master artist! Create a winter wonderland.
instructions.Standalone_Artist_1_instruction: Welcome to Artist! First off, let's try to make a simple square using the turn right block and move forward block. Each side should be 100 pixels long.
instructions.Standalone_Artist_2_instruction: Draw this diamond with 120 and 60 degree angles and 150 pixel long sides.
instructions.Standalone_Artist_3_instruction: Can you draw this hexagon with 100 pixel sides and 60 degree turns?
instructions.Standalone_Artist_4_instruction: Now you've got a new block to play with, the loop. This will repeat a set of commands. What happens if you loop these commands 6 times?
instructions.Standalone_Artist_5.5_instruction: Notice how we simplified the diamond code by turning it into a loop. You can loop that whole sequence 12 times to draw the flower. Hint: You'll need to turn 30 degrees after your diamond loop so you don't keep drawing over the same diamond.
instructions.Standalone_Artist_5_instruction: How many times do you need to loop this diamond to draw the flower?
instructions.Standalone_Artist_6_instruction: Loop this hexagon code 6 times to create the design. How many degrees will you need to turn each time? Hint: divide the number of degrees in a circle by the number of times you are looping.
instructions.Standalone_Artist_7_instruction: A function is another programming tool to help you avoid repeating yourself. This function draws a flower, so you can use it any time you want to draw a flower. Use this and the new jump block to draw these flowers. Hint: The flowers are 150 pixels apart
instructions.Standalone_Artist_8_instruction: Here's a function called "Draw a shape" that we've programmed to draw hexagons. Run the code to see what it does and then experiment with the function to see what happens. Can you make it draw a pattern of squares, triangles, or octagons?
instructions.Standalone_Artist_9_instruction: Now go ahead and make whatever picture you'd like! You've even got an empty function that you can make do whatever you want!
instructions.Standalone_Artist_v2_instruction: Welcome to Artist! First off, let's try to make a simple square using the turn right block and move forward block. Each side should be 100 pixels long.
instructions.Test Play Lab_instruction: This is a test play lab level.
instructions.Test embedded Blockly in instructions_in:
As a block element, we should be able to include XML representing a valid Blockly block or blocks.

moveForward 100

We also support Blockly XML as an inline element like so: moveForward100. The difference in input format being that this one is embedded within a paragraph, whereas the previous one is in a text block of its own. The difference in output is comparable.
instructions.Test embedded K1 Blockly in instructions: Use three move west blocks and one pick corn block to solve this puzzle.
instructions.Test of comment block_instruction: Drag out the subgoal label block you want.
instructions.Testing Quantum Farmer_instruction:
Wow, look at that!

I don't know how many shovelfuls of dirt this hole needs.
Can you write a program that keeps using the fill block until the ground is even?
instructions.Text Compression 1_instruction: Look for patterns (repeated words or phrases) in the text. Enter the patterns you see into the dictionary on the right. As you type entries into the dictionary, the symbol for the entry is inserted into the text in place of the pattern.
instructions.Total Artist Clone Me_instruction: Freeplay: Here are the functions you've written, and some more for you to play with. Draw something awesome! Play with the pen width to see how different your drawings look!
instructions.U1L10 NetSim numbers with decimal_instru: Invent and test a protocol for encoding and sending text messages. Your protocol must include the letters a-z, spaces, and common punctuation marks. You may add additional characters if you wish. See the worksheet handed out by your teacher for more detailed instructions!
instructions.U1L11 NetSim numbers with Ascii_instruct: Work with a partner or in a small team to develop a protocol that allows you to send formatted text. See the worksheet handed out by your teacher for more detailed instructions!
instructions.U1L13 Text Compression_instruction: Look for patterns (repeated words or phrases) in the text. Enter the patterns you see into the dictionary on the right. As you type entries into the dictionary, the symbol for the entry is inserted into the text in place of the pattern.
instructions.U1L4 NetSim SendAB_instruction: Develop, document, and test a protocol that allows you to use Internet Simulator to relay a message. See the worksheet for more detailed instructions.
instructions.U1L8 NetSim numbers with decimal_instruc: With your partner, develop a protocol or set of rules for communicating a drawing using only bits. See the worksheet handed out by your teacher for more detailed instructions!
instructions.U2L04 - NetSim Routers with Addresses_in: Send messages with your classmates (Click to see full instructions)
instructions.U2L05 - NetSim - Packets and Building TC:
Develop a Protocol for Reliably Sending a Message.

Constraints:

  • Packets may contain only 6 characters
  • Packets may drop with small probability
  • Packets may not arrive in order
instructions.U2L10 NetSim Automatic DNS_instruction: In this version of the Internet Simulator, a Domain Name System (DNS) is provided for you and knows the IP addresses of all connected computers. Send a message in the form GET [hostname] to the DNS service at address .15 to get a student's address.
instructions.U2L10 NetSim Manual DNS_instruction: In this version of the simulator you can't see the other students' addresses. Instead, one of you must act as a name service, to help share addresses with each other.
instructions.U2L2 NetSim Hub Mode_instruction: Now use the Internet Simulator to send the battleship moves. For setup, join a Room with your group, and add ships to your paper board for each opponent. When playing, all communication must be done through the tool, so no talking, but have fun!
instructions.U2L3 NetSim Hub Mode_instruction: Use the Internet Simulator to test out your group's binary communication protocol for battleship. How short can you make the message and response?
instructions.U2L4 NetSim Routers Addresses_instructio:
For this activity, connect to a router with the others in your group. Important note: The router will only properly route messages where the first 4 bits are the To: address and the second 4 bits are the From: address.

[TODO: NetSim needs to support hierarchical addresses. For now, level is set up for 4 bit to and from addresses]
instructions.U2L5 NetSim Classroom Internet_instructi: For this activity, connect to a router with the others in your group. The Internet Simulator now provides a place for you to put the To and From addresses, so you don't have to type out the bits manually.
instructions.U2L7 NetSim Need for Packets_instruction: Transfer your favicon to a partner across a network in which the larger a packet grows, the more likely it is to be dropped.

It's also easy to read because the function names describe the expected behavior.

instructions.U3L13 - Debug Id plus logic problem_inst:
The last problem was an example of syntax error. App Lab did not understand which object it should be listening to for a "click" event so it showed an error message in the console to let you know. Another kind of error is a logical error - the program is valid, but it's not doing what you want it to do.

This program has 2 errors. A (tricky) syntax error and logical error. Find them, fix them, and make the program work as expected.

instructions.U3L19 - try out console log_instruction:
Try out console.log. Do this: replace the statement write("foo is: " + foo) with console.log("foo is: " + foo). Run the program and you should see the output show up in the console area below the workspace. Then try adding a few more console.log statements. Display some text. Make another variable and display that.
The app screen will be blank -- that's the point. With console.log you can test output behind the scenes in a way the user cannot see.

instructions.aE1_instruction:
You chose to make a square napkin!

To finish, draw a square with 20 pixel sides.
instructions.aE2_instruction: If you place your square loop inside another loop, we call that a nested loop. What do you need to add as an outer loop to make sure all 14 napkins line up next to each other?
instructions.aE3_instruction:
We've got to have a tablecloth!

Take your row of 14 napkins and sew 14 of those together with another outer loop to make a cover for our table.
instructions.aE5_instruction: Example of puzzle using highest difficulty level shape.
instructions.aE6_instruction: How many times do you need to loop this to draw half of a circle?
instructions.aE7_instruction:
If you create another loop like this one, but turn left instead of right, what happens?

Can you repeat all of that to draw this wave?
instructions.aE8_instruction:
Now let's loop that whole thing four times to create this picture frame. Watch out for the corners - you can't just turn 90 degrees!

If looping a 3 degree turn 60 times makes a half circle, which of these blocks of code will make an additional quarter circle for the corners?

instructions.behaviors pet test 3_instruction:
It's time to make your own virtual pet! You can change whatever code you want to to make your own pet. Here are some ideas:

  • Can you make your pet start a new behavior when you click on it?
  • Can you make your pet run away when you drag the vacuum to it?
  • Can you add other animal friends to your pet's area?
instructions.behaviors pet test_instruction:
Last time, you practiced using "behaviors" to make a sprite do something forever. This time, we will use behaviors to make a virtual pet.

This dog's name is Daisy. Daisy LOVES to snack on carrots. Add the "drag and drop" behavior to the carrot so you can move it to her.

instructions.bounce_1_instruction: Attach a block to the "when left arrow" block and press "Run". Move the paddle using the left arrow to reach the finish target.
instructions.bounce_10_instruction: There is now a goal at the top. Attach the "score point" and "score opponent point" blocks to the "when ball in goal" and "when ball misses paddle" blocks to make a game. See how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice.
instructions.bounce_10_2018_instruction: There is now a goal at the top. Attach the "score point" and "score opponent point" blocks to the "when ball in goal" and "when ball misses paddle" blocks to make a game. See how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice.
instructions.bounce_10_basketball_instruction: Now there is a goal at the top! Attach the "score point" and "score opponent point" blocks to the "when ball in goal" and "when ball misses hand" blocks to make a game. See how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice.
instructions.bounce_10_sports_instruction: Now there is a goal at the top! Attach the "score point" and "score opponent point" blocks to the "when ball in goal" and "when ball misses hand" blocks to make a game. See how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice!
instructions.bounce_11_instruction: You can now attach blocks to the "when run" block. You have to attach the new "launch new ball" block in more than one place. Also, try changing the scene or the speed of the paddle and the ball and see how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice.
instructions.bounce_11_2018_instruction: You can now attach blocks to the "when run" block. You have to attach the new "launch new ball" block in more than one place. Also, try changing the scene or the speed of the paddle and the ball and see how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice.
instructions.bounce_11_basketball_instruction: You can now attach blocks to the "when run" block. You have to attach the new "throw new ball" block in more than one place. Also, try changing the scene or the speed of the hand and the ball and see how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice!
instructions.bounce_11_sports_instruction: You can now attach blocks to the "when run" block. You have to attach the new "throw new ball" block in more than one place. Also, try changing the scene or the speed of the hand and the ball and see how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice!

instructions.frozen circle function in circle_instruc: Now let's create 20 overlapping circles, turning 18 degrees between each circle.
instructions.frozen circle function with parameter_in: Here's a â€Create circleâ€ block that can make circles of different sizes. Can you use this to create a small circle of size 5 and a larger circle of size 10?
instructions.frozen circle function_instruction: Use the new â€œCreate a circleâ€ block to create 10 overlapping circles. Don't forget to jump forward between circles.
instructions.frozen circle_instruction: A circle is a special shape. Can you figure out what number to replace the question marks with to draw a circle?
instructions.frozen cross rotate dense_instruction: Let's repeat it 90 times! How many times does 90 go into 360? Hint: It's a really small number.
instructions.frozen cross rotate_instruction: Now try repeating it 10 times. How many degrees do you need to turn between each line?
instructions.frozen cross_instruction: Wrap a â€œRepeatâ€ block around these commands to create a plus sign. Did you notice Elsa can move forward and backward?
instructions.frozen diamond mini snowflake_instructio: Did you know every snowflake is a different shape? Let's create a new snowflake by using another â€œRepeat" block to repeat a parallelogram 4 times, turning right by 90 degrees between each parallelogram.
instructions.frozen diamond snowflake_instruction: Now, let's create a new snowflake by using the repeat block to repeat a parallelogram 10 times, turning right by 36 degrees between each one.
instructions.frozen diamond_instruction: Use a repeat around these blocks to create a parallelogram. It's just like a rectangle but has different angles. This one has 60 degree and 120 degree angles instead of all 90 degree angles.
instructions.frozen freeplay_instruction: You've officially become a master artist! Create a winter wonderland.
instructions.frozen line_instruction: Hi! I'm Elsa of Arendelle. Help me create a single line.
instructions.frozen perpendicular_instruction: Now let's see if we can create two lines that are at a 90 degree angle to each other. You will need to use the "Turn" block as well as the "Move" block.
instructions.frozen snowflake branch_instruction: Try using the â€Create a snowflake branchâ€ block to create three branches, which starts to look like a snowflake.
instructions.frozen snowflake full_instruction: Now let's repeat it 8 times to make a beautiful snowflake!
instructions.frozen snowflower_instruction: Intricate snow patterns can be created with very simple shapes. Can you make a pattern by repeating 5 circles of size 5 and 5 circles of size 10?
instructions.frozen square iterative_instruction: It seems like we're halfway to making a square. Let's put 4 lines together to create a square.
instructions.frozen square loop 3x_instruction: Let's create three squares, turning after each square. Be sure to turn by 120 degrees before each new square.
instructions.frozen square loop_instruction: Hi, Iâ€™m Anna of Arendelle! Letâ€™s make a square with the â€œRepeatâ€ block, which uses fewer blocks. How many times (???) should the â€œRepeatâ€ block loop the blocks inside it to make a square?
instructions.frozen square snowflake_instruction: Can you create a snowflake using the â€œRepeatâ€ block to make a square 10 times, and the â€œTurnâ€ block to turn 36 degrees between each square?

instructions.grade2_MakeDogTag_FP_instruction: Freeplay: What shape will you make the tag for your pet?
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_1_instruction: Can you get me to the pig using 5 of the same kind of blocks?
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_10_instruction:
My teacher says that I should finish what I start!

Help me finish my pinwheel. Can you figure out what's wrong?
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_2_instruction: Can you get to the pig by creating a loop that uses only one move forward block inside of a repeat?
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_3_instruction: Get me to the pig! Solve this puzzle by creating a loop!
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_4_instruction: In this puzzle, two repeat loops will help you get to the pig with the fewest number of blocks!
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_5_instruction: Can you figure out the fastest way to get me to the pig?
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_6_instruction: Loops even work with more than one block inside! Can you loop this sequence to get me to the pig?
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_7_instruction: Use what you learned to get me to the sunflower!

This code for the cat's whiskers is wrong.

Fix this code to draw whiskers that are all the same length.
instructions.grade2_PuppyLoops_9_instruction:
Looks like the C in code is drawn backwards!

Can you make it look like a C again?
instructions.grade2_collector_10_instruction: You're almost done! Collect as many pieces of treasure as you can to finish the stage!
instructions.grade2_collector_10_2018_instruction: You're almost done! Collect as many pieces of treasure as you can to finish the stage!

instructions.grade2_collector_5_instruction: These blocks are in the wrong order. Can you fix them?

instructions.grade2_collector_A_2018_instruction: Help Laurel collect all of the treasure.

"Hi, I'm Laurel. Today I'm searching for treasure at the dog park!"

Play around with the blocks to see if you can help Laurel collect some gold.

instructions.grade2_maze_debuggingPre_instruction: Play with these blocks to see what they make the bird do!
instructions.grade2_maze_intro2_instruction: Welcome to Code Studio! Here you will learn to use blocks to build programs. Press Run to run a program now!
instructions.grade2_maze_intro3_instruction: The workspace is where you will create all of your programs. Can you guess what this program does? Press the â€œRunâ€ button to find out.
instructions.grade2_maze_intro4_instruction: Drag a block from the toolbox into the workspace. Connect it to the other blocks.
instructions.grade2_maze_intro6_instruction: Thatâ€™s it! Now weâ€™re ready to try to solve a few puzzles.
instructions.grade2_maze_intro7_instruction: This time, try something a bit more challenging.

If you donâ€™t solve it after several tries, donâ€™t worry! It will be in the Play Zone at the end of the stage and you can try it again when youâ€™ve had more practice.
instructions.grade2_playlab_project_1_instruction: Now, write a program to make Waddles move around using the up / down / left /right keys to hit all of the targets!
instructions.grade2_playlab_project_2_instruction: The repeat forever block allows you to run code over and over forever. Can you attach blocks to move Chomp the Dino (actor 2) up and down forever?
instructions.grade2_playlab_project_3_instruction:
Can you have Waddles (actor 1) say "Ouch!" and play a "hit" sound if he runs into Chomp?

When you're done, play the game to make that happen.
instructions.grade2_playlab_project_4_instruction: Can you add a block to score a point when Waddles runs into Octavia (actor 3)? Play the game and move Waddles with the arrows until you score!
instructions.grade2_playlab_project_5_instruction:
Add blocks to the when run event to change the background and the speed of Waddles.

Play the game and move Waddles with the arrows until you score.
instructions.grade2_playlab_project_6_instruction: Create your own story. When you're done, click "Finish" to share with friends.
