instructions.grade3_AboutMyRobot_1_instruction: Make your robot say "Hello!" when the button is clicked.
instructions.grade3_AboutMyRobot_2_instruction: Edit the code so that when the second bird is clicked, your program plays a sound!
instructions.grade3_AboutMyRobot_3_instruction: When the third bird is clicked, the background should change to a city. Can you add code to make this happen?
instructions.grade3_AboutMyRobot_4_instruction: Add code to make something happen when the fourth bird is clicked. Be creative!
instructions.grade3_AboutMyRobot_5_instruction: About My Robot Project! Write code so that clicking on each bird shows a new fact about your robot.
instructions.grade3_AboutMyRobot_TeacherIDo_instructi: Run this puzzle and click on the robot to see what happens!
instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_1_instruction: This cloud is blocking my view! Check to see if there's a flower under the cloud, and only get nectar if there's a flower. Be careful, it can change!
instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_2_instruction:
More clouds!

Check underneath every cloud to see if it is hiding a flower before you get nectar.

Remember: Not all clouds hide the same thing!
instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_3_instruction: Now I just want to make honey. Some of these clouds might have honeycombs under them. Be sure to check each cloud!
instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_4_instruction: Sometimes this cloud covers a flower, and sometimes it covers a honeycomb! Use the if/else block to collect nectar if it is a flower, else to make honey (because it is a honeycomb).
instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_5_instruction:
There will be either a flower or a honeycomb under each of those clouds!

Use the if/else block to collect nectar if there is a flower. Otherwise, make honey (because there is a honeycomb).
instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_6_instruction:
I am not sure how much nectar this flower has, but I know it has either 1, 2, or 3 nectar.

Combine the conditional blocks (if and/or if/else) to only get as much nectar as the flower has.

Remember, the amount of nectar can change each time you run the puzzle!
instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_7_instruction:
These flowers can have 3, 2, or 1 nectar.

Complete the check purple flower function and use it to collect all of the nectar at the flowers.
instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_8_instruction:
Write the function for check flower make honey.

Your function should check if the purple flower has 3, 2, or 1 nectar and get all of the nectar. Then, move forward and make honey.
instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_9_instruction:
Assessment: This cloud is either hiding a flower with one nectar or a honeycomb that needs one honey.

Complete the get nectar or make honey function, then call it to collect the nectar or honey.
instructions.grade3_ConditionalsElse_TeacherIDo_instr:
There will be either a flower or a honeycomb under each of those clouds!

Use the if/else block to collect nectar if there is a flower. Otherwise, make honey (because there is a honeycomb).
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_1 BAD_instruction: Use a loop to collect all of the nectar.
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_1_instruction: I'm a hungry bee! Help me collect all of the nectar from the flowers using the fewest number of blocks.
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_10 BAD_instruction: Gather nectar from the rows of flowers! Use a nested loop.
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_10_instruction:
There's a lot happening here!

Use what you've learned to collect all of the nectar and then make the honey.
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_11 BAD_instruction: Assessment: Use a while loop to collect all of the nectar from these flowers.
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_11_instruction:
Let's put everything together!

Use what you've learned to help me collect nectar only from flowers that have it, using as few blocks as possible. Don't forget to make honey at the end.
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_12_instruction:
This stair step pattern should look familiar.

Can you collect nectar only from the flowers that have some, using as few blocks as possible?
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_13_instruction: Assessment: Collect all of the nectar. Be careful not to try to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any.
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_2_instruction:
Look at all of that nectar!

Help me collect the nectar and make the honey using as few blocks as you can.
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_3_instruction: Be careful not to collect nectar from a purple flower if it doesn't have any. You must first check if the nectar is equal to 1 using the if nectar block.
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_4_instruction: Check this flower with an "if" block to see if there is any nectar available.
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_5_instruction: Collect nectar from each flower only if it has any.
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_6_instruction: This field has red and purple flowers. Red flowers have a known nectar amount, but purple flower nectar is unknown. Collect all the nectar.
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_7_instruction: Collect all the nectar from each flower.
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_8_instruction:
I wonder what's out there!

Help me fly around the yard and collect nectar only from the flowers that have some.
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_9_instruction: Help me find all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible!
instructions.grade3_Conditionals_TeacherIDo_instructi: Check this flower with an "if" block to see if there is any nectar available.
instructions.grade3_Debugging_1_instruction: These blocks are really bugging me. Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.
instructions.grade3_Debugging_5_instruction:
That flower looks tasty!

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar. You can now use both run and step.
instructions.grade3_Debugging_6_instruction:
What a sweet challenge!

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar.
instructions.grade3_Debugging_7_instruction: Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
instructions.grade3_Debugging_9_instruction:
"Bee" patient with this one!

You will need to fix a couple of things in this program to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
instructions.grade3_Debugging_TeacherIDo_instruction: These blocks are really bugging me. Fix the error(s) to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
instructions.grade3_Loops_1_instruction: Can you help me collect the nectar from these flowers?
instructions.grade3_Loops_10_instruction:
Such a busy bee!

Help bee collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey with the fewest blocks possible.
instructions.grade3_Loops_11_instruction:
The shape of this path is different than the others.

Can you collect all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible?
instructions.grade3_Loops_12_instruction: Can you find the quickest way for the bee to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey?
instructions.grade3_Loops_2_instruction: This time, use a loop to gather all of the nectar.
instructions.grade3_Loops_3_instruction: Use a repeat loop to collect all of the nectar.
instructions.grade3_Loops_4_instruction: Now use the repeat block to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
instructions.grade3_Loops_5_instruction: What a beautiful field of flowers! Help the bee visit each one. Can you find a way to do it with fewer than 7 blocks?
instructions.grade3_Loops_6_instruction:
How many times can loops help you in this puzzle?

Loops are your friend! Use a few of them to complete this puzzle with the fewest blocks possible.
instructions.grade3_Loops_7_instruction:
Those flowers look tasty!

Collect nectar from each of the flowers using the fewest blocks possible.
instructions.grade3_Loops_8_instruction: Collect all the nectar and make all of the honey using the fewest blocks possible.
instructions.grade3_Loops_9_instruction: Collect nectar from each flower and make honey at each honeycomb using the fewest blocks possible.
instructions.grade3_Loops_TeacherIDo_instruction:
Those flowers look tasty!

Collect nectar from each of the flowers using the fewest blocks possible.
instructions.grade3_RunningFarm_1_instruction: Use conditionals to make sure that you pick all of the corn, but don't disturb the stalks where nothing is growing yet.
instructions.grade3_RunningFarm_10_instruction: Collect all of the corn and lettuce, then pick the pumpkin.
instructions.grade3_RunningFarm_11a_instruction: Collect all of the corn and lettuce, then pick the pumpkin.
instructions.grade3_RunningFarm_2_instruction: Help the farmer collect both corn and lettuce from the field.
instructions.grade3_RunningFarm_3_instruction: "Corn, lettuce, AND pumpkins! Help me harvest them all."
instructions.grade3_RunningFarm_4_instruction: Help the farmer pick all of the lettuce in each cluster before moving on to the next bunch.
instructions.grade3_RunningFarm_5_instruction: This field has clusters of corn, lettuce, and pumpkins all growing together. Can you collect them all?
instructions.grade3_RunningFarm_6_instruction: Can you figure out how to pick the pumpkin? Make sure to collect all of the corn along the way!
instructions.grade3_RunningFarm_7_instruction: Challenge: Collect all of the corn and lettuce, then pick the pumpkin.
instructions.grade3_RunningFarm_8_instruction: Have wheat and potatoes planted randomly at various growth stages. Now we introduce multiple while loops (stacked) nested inside a loop. The two while loops in the solution represent different while loops (while there is potato and while there is wheat)
instructions.grade3_RunningFarm_9_instruction: Add Weeds element. Weeds start out in random spots in the field and spread more and more rapidly as time goes on.. This puzzle is the culminating game-like puzzle. Students should have the event blocks (up, down, left, right, spacebar) available in the toolbox to use if they want. The entire field should be planted randomly with mostly wheat, potatoes, and a few weeds.
instructions.grade3_RunningFarm_TeacherIDo_instructio: Teacher I Do: Show students how they can use loops and conditionals to plant and harvest 2 rows of crops.
instructions.grade3_RunningFarm_TeacherIDo2_instructi: Teacher I Do: Show students how to use loops to harvest many crops.
instructions.grade3_bee_Conditionals_new4_instruction: Now try checking all of these flowers with "if" blocks to see if there is any nectar available.
instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_new1a_instructio:
Help the bee collect all of the nectar.

You can only collect nectar from flowers, but you can check any space to see if there is a flower.
instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_new1b_instructio: Help the bee collect all of the nectar. You can only collect nectar from flowers, but you can check any space to see if there is a flower.
instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_new2_instruction: Collect all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible
instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_new2a_instructio: Get all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible.
instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_new2b_instructio: Collect all of the nectar. You can only collect nectar from flowers, but you can check any space to see if there is a flower.
instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_new3a_instructio: Collect all of the nectar or make all the honey. You can only collect nectar from flowers and make honey from honeycombs. Check any space to see if there is a flower or honeycomb.
instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_new3b_instructio: Collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_new3c_instructio: Help the bee collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey! Hint: Try using one loop inside of another loop.
instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_quantum1_instruc: Check to see if there's a flower under the cloud. If there's a flower, get nectar.
instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_quantum2_instruc: Check underneath every cloud to see if it is hiding a flower before you get nectar.
instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_quantum3_instruc: Some of these clouds might have honeycombs under them. Be sure to check if a honeycomb is hiding behind each cloud!
instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_quantum4_instruc: Use the if/else block to collect nectar at flowers and make honey at honeycomb.
instructions.grade3_bee_conditionals_quantum5_instruc: Use the if/else block to collect nectar if there is a flower. Otherwise, make honey (because there is a honeycomb).
instructions.grade3_maze_Loop1_instruction: Assessment: Get me to the sunflower using only 5 blocks!
instructions.grade3_maze_loops2_instruction: Get the zombie to the sunflower using the fewest blocks possible!
instructions.grade3_maze_loops2a_instruction: Get the zombie to the sunflower using the fewest number of blocks possible.
instructions.grade3_maze_loops3_instruction: Get the zombie to the sunflower using only the blocks available.
instructions.grade3_maze_loops4_instruction: Get the zombe to the sunflower using the fewest number of blocks possible!
instructions.grade3_maze_loops5_instruction: Get me to the sunflower using the fewest blocks possible!
instructions.grade3_maze_nestedLoops1_instruction: Can you get me to the pig using 5 of the same kind of blocks?
instructions.grade3_maze_nestedLoops2_instruction: Can you get to the pig by creating a loop that uses only one move forward block inside of a repeat?
instructions.grade3_maze_nestedLoops3_instruction: Get me to the pig! You can only use one move forward block this time
instructions.grade3_maze_nestedLoops4_instruction: In this puzzle, two repeat loops will help you get to the pig with the fewest number of blocks!
instructions.grade3_playLab_buildGame_1_instruction: There is a new block in this lesson, the random integer block. It is used to choose a random number. Write a program where the robot says a random number between 1 and 100!
instructions.grade3_playLab_buildGame_2_instruction: We have already created a random integer, "j", which is either 1 or 0. Now, we need to use it to decide whether our card is red or black. Add a second if statement to the code under when run to complete this code.
instructions.grade3_playLab_buildGame_3_instruction: There are 13 different card values in a deck of cards, so we'll need to have 13 options. Under the empty when run block, add a line that sets the placeholder "i" to a random integer between 1 and 13.
instructions.grade3_playLab_buildGame_4_instruction: In a deck of cards, a card with value 1 isn't actually called a "1", there's a special name. Write an if statement that checks if the random number is a 1, then tell the computer that the value of that card is "Ace".
instructions.grade3_playLab_buildGame_5_instruction: We can just call the cards from 2 to 10 by their numbers, so add an if statement that checks whether the number generated is within those numbers, then sets the card value to the number generated.
instructions.grade3_playLab_buildGame_6_instruction: There are three more cards with special names in the deck. Add to your code so that a card number 11 is called a "Jack", a 12 is a "Queen" and a 13 is a "King"
instructions.grade3_playLab_buildGame_7_instruction: You already know what color your card is, but what suit is it? Add code to the conditional statement "if card is Red" to choose hearts or diamonds.
instructions.grade3_playLab_buildGame_8_instruction: Add the second part of the code to choose a suit, copying what you made for a Red card.
instructions.grade3_playLab_buildGame_final_instructi: Final stage for playlab conditionals level (could hide entire function so that students just work with point scoring)
instructions.grade3_playLab_buildGame_final2_instruct: Here's all of your code to choose a card - try adding some other fun features!
instructions.grade3_robotFarmer_ConditionalsIntro4_in: Help the farmer remove this entire pile using a while loop.
instructions.grade3_robotFarmer_ConditionalsIntro_1_i:
"Hi, I'm a farmer. I need your help to flatten the field on my farm so it's ready for planting!"

Move to the pile of dirt and use the remove block to remove it.
instructions.grade3_robotFarmer_ConditionalsIntro_10_: I'm working late, so it's dark out, and I can't tell how large the piles are. Now I don't have all the options I used to have on the while block. Move me along the field, and if there is a pile, remove it
instructions.grade3_robotFarmer_ConditionalsIntro_10a: Flatten all of these piles using as few blocks as possible.
instructions.grade3_robotFarmer_ConditionalsIntro_11_: It's still dark outside. Move me along the field. If there is a pile, remove it, and if there is a hole, fill it in. Hint: use the dropdown menu of options on the "if" block.
instructions.grade3_robotFarmer_ConditionalsIntro_11a: Flatten all of these piles using as few blocks as possible.
instructions.grade3_robotFarmer_ConditionalsIntro_2_i: Next, move to the hole and fill it with six shovelfuls of dirt, using the fill block.
instructions.grade3_robotFarmer_ConditionalsIntro_3_i: "Move to the pile of dirt and tell me how many shovelfuls to remove using as few blocks as possible."
instructions.grade3_robotFarmer_ConditionalsIntro_4_i:
"I don't know how much dirt is in this pile!"

Help the farmer remove this entire pile using a while loop.
instructions.grade3_robotFarmer_ConditionalsIntro_5_i: Help me remove all of this dirt.
instructions.grade3_robotFarmer_ConditionalsIntro_6_i: Remove all the piles of dirt, using as few blocks as possible. The new options in the dropdown menu on the "while" block tell me if I'm standing on a pile or a hole.
instructions.grade3_robotFarmer_ConditionalsIntro_7_i:
Look at all of those holes! Each one needs a different amount of dirt.

You can use the while loop to easily fill them all!
instructions.grade3_robotFarmer_ConditionalsIntro_8_i: Fill in the hole at the end of each of these paths.
instructions.grade3_robotFarmer_ConditionalsIntro_9_i: Challenge: Fill all of these holes using as few blocks as possible.
instructions.grade3_robotFarmer_ConditionalsIntro_Tea: Help me fill in all these holes with 5 shovelfuls of dirt. Hint: you can put a "repeat" block inside the "while" block.

I'm working late, so it's dark out, and I can't tell how large the piles are. Now I don't have all the options I used to have on the while block. Move me along the field, and if there is a pile, remove it
instructions.grade4_arist_functions_star0_instruction: Have you drawn something like this star before? Practice making it one more time by adding a turn and a repeat block.
instructions.grade4_arist_nested_loop_circles1_instru: Assessment: Use a nested loop to complete the design.
instructions.grade4_arist_nested_loop_flags1_instruct: Loop the given code to create a windmill.
instructions.grade4_arist_nested_loop_polygons1_instr:
Loop this design 10 times.

How much do you have to turn each time you loop?
instructions.grade4_arist_nested_loop_polygons2_instr:
Loop this shape 6 times.

How much do you have to turn each time you loop?
instructions.grade4_arist_nested_loop_squares1_instru: Can you draw these 10 squares of this sidewalk using a nested loop? Each square is 30 pixels.
instructions.grade4_arist_nested_loop_triangles2_inst: Now nest this loop inside another loop to draw 10 triangles. This is called a "nested" loop.
instructions.grade4_arist_nested_loop_triangles3_inst: Can you draw a hexagon by looping the triangle code?
instructions.grade4_arist_nested_loop_triangles4_inst: Draw the teeth in the alligator's mouth!
instructions.grade4_arist_nested_loop_triangles5_inst:
Create a sun by nesting the starter code in another loop.

To get this cool design with a hollow center, you'll need to jump forward by the length of the triangle before turning.
instructions.grade4_arist_nested_loop_triangles6_inst: Can you draw these 36 triangles using a nested loop?
instructions.grade4_artist_freeplay_instruction: You are on your own now! Try out any of the functions you used in this stage or try this new function that will automatically give your image a beautiful background color! This creation will be saved to your Projects dashboard so that you can easily edit it any time!
instructions.grade4_artist_functions1_instruction:
Help the zombie draw glasses using squares with sides of 100 pixels.
The bridge between the glasses is 75 pixels long.
instructions.grade4_artist_functions2_instruction:
Functions let you define new blocks!

We've moved the blocks needed for drawing a square into a function called draw a square. This time, use the draw a square function to create the glasses.

The squares are 75 pixels apart.
instructions.grade4_artist_functions2a_instruction: Create this image using only the blocks provided.
instructions.grade4_artist_functions3a_instruction: Create this image using only the blocks provided.
instructions.grade4_artist_functions3b_instruction: This time, use lines of 8 hexagons with 25 pixel sides.
instructions.grade4_artist_functionsChallenge0_instru: Challenge: Create as many functions as you think you need to make this drawing of 50 pixel squares.
instructions.grade4_artist_functions_challenge_instru: Use the suggested functions to draw four rows of hexagons. Notice how our even numbered rows are shifted to the right?
instructions.grade4_artist_functions_challenge2_instr: Use the suggested functions to draw four rows of hexagons. Notice how our even numbered rows are shifted to the right?
instructions.grade4_artist_functions_freeplay_instruc: You are on your own now! Try out any of the functions you used in this stage or try this new function that will automatically give your image a beautiful background color! This creation will be saved to your Projects dashboard so that you can easily edit it any time!
instructions.grade4_artist_functions_stars0_instructi: You can make this drawing by adding a repeat block.
instructions.grade4_artist_functions_stars1_instructi: Now that you can draw a star, try drawing four stars!
instructions.grade4_artist_functions_stars2_instructi: Draw only those three stars to finish this puzzle.
instructions.grade4_artist_functions_stars3_instructi: That last one is tough if you only use loops. Let's try drawing the same picture using this new 'function' that will help to draw a star.
instructions.grade4_artist_functions_windows0_instruc: Make this window by drawing a square, then turning 90 degrees before drawing another, and so on.
instructions.grade4_artist_functions_windows1_instruc: If you can draw one window, you can draw three! Try using your choice of a nested loop or a function here. Don't forget the jump block!
instructions.grade4_artist_functions_windows2_instruc:
Try solving this puzzle by creating draw a window and calling it five times. Watch out for the door!

  • The top windows are 50 pixels away from each other.
  • The bottom windows are 100 pixels below the top set.
instructions.grade4_artist_nestedLoops_challenge_inst:
Click here to see the full instructions again!

Here is the code for an interesting shape. What happens when you repeat it multiple times, turning between each iteration? Notice that the turns in this shape add up to 420 degrees, which means that when your artist is done drawing, it will be facing a different direction than when you started. That new direction is exactly 60 degrees to the right of where you began.
instructions.grade4_artist_nestedLoops_challenge2_ins: Now for a challenge! Feel free to use trial and error. You are not expected to get the image perfect the first time. Want to see more hints? Click here!
instructions.grade4_artist_nested_loop_circles1_instr: Assessment: Use a nested loop to complete the design.
instructions.grade4_artist_nested_loop_flags1_instruc: Loop the given code to create a windmill.
instructions.grade4_artist_nested_loop_polygons1_inst:
Loop this design 10 times.

How much do you have to turn each time you loop?
instructions.grade4_artist_nested_loop_polygons2_inst:
Hi, I'm the Artist! Let's create some drawings together! For starters, try repeating this shape 6 times.

How much do you have to turn each time you loop?
instructions.grade4_artist_nested_loop_squares1_instr: Can you draw these 10 squares of this sidewalk using a nested loop? Each square is 30 pixels.
instructions.grade4_artist_nested_loop_triangles1_ins: Complete the code to draw these triangles. The first one is done for you. Hint: 3 triangles in a 360 degree rotation.
instructions.grade4_artist_nested_loop_triangles2_ins:
Let's make a quick adjustment to get completely different image!
Hint: ? Ã— 10 = 360
instructions.grade4_artist_nested_loop_triangles3_ins: Can you draw a hexagon by looping the triangle code? Hint: 6 Ã— ? = 360
instructions.grade4_artist_nested_loop_triangles4_ins: Hi! I'm the Artist. Let's try some different types of drawings together. Can you help me draw the bottom teeth in the alligator's mouth?
instructions.grade4_artist_nested_loop_triangles5_ins:
Create a sun by nesting the starter code in another loop.

To get this cool design with a hollow center, you'll need to jump forward by the length of the triangle before turning.
instructions.grade4_artist_nested_loop_triangles6_ins: Can you draw these 36 triangles using a nested loop?
instructions.grade4_artist_parameters_squares1_instru: Click "edit" to fill in the function definition of "draw a square" and add a parameter. It should take a length parameter, just like the triangle. This time, draw 3 squares: 25, 50 and 75 pixels in length, each 100 pixels apart.
instructions.grade4_artist_parameters_triangles1_inst: Today, we're going to try out a different, more powerful function editor. See if you can figure out how to edit the function 'draw a triangle' to find the bugs.
instructions.grade4_artist_parameters_triangles2_inst: Do you notice anything different about these function blocks? Click â€œRunâ€ to see what happens.
instructions.grade4_artist_parameters_triangles2b_ins: Can you complete this drawing? The sides of each triangle are 25 pixels larger than the last. The first triangle has 25 pixel sides.
instructions.grade4_artist_parameters_triangles3_inst: Can you complete this drawing? The sides of each triangle are 25 pixels larger than the last. The first triangle has 25 pixel sides.
instructions.grade4_artist_parameters_triangles4_inst: The code for this triangle function is broken. Can you edit the function to fix it, and then make triangles of length 25, 50, and 75?
instructions.grade4_artist_parameters_trianglesx_inst: Can you complete this drawing? The sides of each triangle are 25 pixels larger than the last. The first triangle has 25 pixel sides.
instructions.grade4_bee_conditionals_nested_loops_ins: Collect all of the nectar. You can only collect nectar from flowers, but you can check any space to see if there is a flower.
instructions.grade4_bee_conditionals_new1_instruction: Collect all of the nectar. You can only collect nectar from flowers, but you can check any space to see if there is a flower.
instructions.grade4_bee_conditionals_new1a_instructio: Help the bee make all of the honey. You can only make honey at a honeycomb, but you can check any space to see if there is a honeycomb.
instructions.grade4_bee_conditionals_new2_instruction: Can you help the bee collect the nectar from the flowers? You can only collect nectar from flowers, but you can check any space to see if there is a flower.
instructions.grade4_bee_conditionals_new2a_instructio: Make all of the honey. It's actually more efficient to check each space for a honey comb, even when you know some are empty.
instructions.grade4_bee_conditionals_new3a_instructio: Collect all of the nectar or make all the honey. You can only collect nectar from flowers and make honey from honeycombs. Check any space to see if there is a flower or honeycomb.
instructions.grade4_bee_conditionals_new3b_instructio: Uh oh! The bee is not sure if he should collect nectar or make honey. Can you help him out?
instructions.grade4_bee_conditionals_new3c_instructio: Help the bee collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey! Hint: Try using one loop inside of another loop.
instructions.grade4_bee_conditionals_quantum1_instruc: This cloud is blocking my view! Check to see if there's a flower under the cloud, and only get nectar if there's a flower. Be careful, it can change!
instructions.grade4_bee_conditionals_quantum2_instruc:
More clouds!

Check underneath every cloud to see if it is hiding a flower before you get nectar.

Remember: Not all clouds hide the same thing!
instructions.grade4_bee_conditionals_quantum3_instruc: Now I just want to make honey. Some of these clouds might have honeycombs under them. The way we've been going about things won't work here. Be sure to check if a honeycomb is hiding behind each cloud!
instructions.grade4_bee_conditionals_quantum4_instruc: Sometimes this cloud covers a flower, and sometimes it covers a honeycomb! Use the if/else block to collect nectar if it is a flower, else to make honey (because it is a honeycomb).
instructions.grade4_bee_conditionals_quantum5_instruc:
There will be either a flower or a honeycomb under each of those clouds!

Use the if/else block to collect nectar if there is a flower. Otherwise, make honey (because there is a honeycomb).
instructions.grade4_bee_functions_instruction: Have we met before? I'm the farmer! Please help me remove this pile of dirt and fill this hole.
instructions.grade4_bee_functions1_instruction: Collect all the nectar from each flower.
instructions.grade4_bee_functions10_instruction: Create a function to collect all of the nectar from each flower.
instructions.grade4_bee_functions11_instruction: Solve this function by creating a function to turn, move forward and make all of the honey, then return the bee to where it started and turn back.
instructions.grade4_bee_functions2_instruction: Functions are blocks of code that perform a task. Use the "get 2 nectar" function to collect the nectar from each flower.
instructions.grade4_bee_functions3_instruction: Build the get 5 function to use in this puzzle.
instructions.grade4_bee_functions4_instruction: Use the move and get nectar function to collect all of the nectar.
instructions.grade4_bee_functions6_instruction: Now write the function to collect nectar from the flowers.
instructions.grade4_bee_functions7_instruction: Create a function and call it to collect nectar at each flower and make honey at each honeycomb.
instructions.grade4_bee_functions8_instruction: Create your own function that goes down a path, gets nectar, makes honey, and then returns the bee to the top of the path. Then collect all the nectar and make all the honey!
instructions.grade4_bee_functions9_instruction: Create a function that collects all of the nectar from each flower.
instructions.grade4_bee_nestedLoops0_instruction: Use a loop to collect all of the nectar.
instructions.grade4_bee_nestedLoops1_instruction: Collect all of the nectar from each flower.
instructions.grade4_bee_nestedLoops2_instruction: Challenge: Figure out how to get all of the nectar using only the blocks available.
instructions.grade4_bee_nestedLoops2a_instruction: Collect all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible.
instructions.grade4_bee_nestedLoops3_instruction: Collect all of the nectar by creating a nested loop.
instructions.grade4_bee_nestedLoops4_instruction: Collect all of the nectar from each flower and make honey at the honeycomb.
instructions.grade4_bee_nestedLoops_assess_instructio:
Assessment: Collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey using loops.

Hint: There are several possible solutions!
instructions.grade4_designProcess_vid_instruction: Prepare to build a project within some given parameters.
instructions.grade4_farmer_functions1_instruction:
"Have we met before? I'm the farmer!"

Help the farmer get to the pumpkins and pick them.
instructions.grade4_farmer_functions2_instruction: Take the code you just wrote it and use it to define a new function. Call the function twice to complete the puzzle.
instructions.grade4_farmer_functions3_instruction: Try using a couple of repeat blocks within your function definition.
instructions.grade4_farmer_functions4_instruction: Swap out your repeat loops for more versatile while loops.
instructions.grade4_farmer_functions5_instruction: Things are going to start getting trickier, but don't give up! You can use the same while loops to check both spaces in each pass.
instructions.grade4_farmer_functions6_instruction: The paths are a different length. You can use a different type of while loop to keep the pattern going as long as you need to.
instructions.grade4_frozen_freeplay_instruction: You've officially become a master artist! Create a winter wonderland.
instructions.grade4_frozen_functions0_instruction: Can you figure out what number to replace the question marks with to draw a circle?
instructions.grade4_frozen_functions1_instruction: Use the new â€œdraw a circleâ€ function to create 10 overlapping circles. Don't forget to jump forward between circles.
instructions.grade4_frozen_functions1a_instruction: Use the new â€œCreate a circleâ€ block to create 10 overlapping circles. Don't forget to jump forward between circles.
instructions.grade4_frozen_functions2_instruction: Now let's create 20 overlapping circles, turning 18 degrees between each circle.
instructions.grade4_frozen_functions3_instruction: Here's a â€Create circleâ€ block that can make circles of different sizes. Can you use this to create a small circle of size 5 and a larger circle of size 10?
instructions.grade4_frozen_functions4_instruction: Intricate snow patterns can be created with very simple shapes. Can you make a pattern by repeating 5 circles of size 5 and 5 circles of size 10?
instructions.grade4_frozen_nested_loop_diamonds1_inst: Letâ€™s use a repeat block to create a rhombus. Like a square, all sides are equal length, but the angles are different. This one has 60 degree and 120 degree angles instead of all 90 degree angles.
instructions.grade4_frozen_nested_loop_diamonds2_inst: Did you know every snowflake is a different shape? Let's create a new snowflake by using another â€œRepeat" block to repeat a parallelogram 4 times, turning right by 90 degrees between each parallelogram.
instructions.grade4_frozen_nested_loop_diamonds3_inst: Now, let's create a new snowflake by using the repeat block to repeat a parallelogram 10 times, turning right by 36 degrees between each one.
instructions.grade4_frozen_nested_loop_rectangle1_ins: Hi, Iâ€™m Anna of Arendelle! Letâ€™s use a repeat block to create a rectangle. This one is 200 pixels long and 100 pixels tall. All of the corners are 90 degree angles.
instructions.grade4_frozen_square_instruction: Hi, Iâ€™m Anna of Arendelle! Letâ€™s make a square with the â€œRepeatâ€ block, which uses fewer blocks. How many times (???) should the â€œRepeatâ€ block loop the blocks inside it to make a square?
instructions.grade4_frozen_square_loop1_instruction: Hi, Iâ€™m Anna of Arendelle! Letâ€™s make a square with the â€œRepeatâ€ block, which uses fewer blocks. How many times (???) should the â€œRepeatâ€ block loop the blocks inside it to make a square?
instructions.grade4_frozen_square_loop2_instruction: Let's create three squares, turning after each square. Be sure to turn by 120 degrees before each new square.
instructions.grade4_frozen_square_loop3_instruction: Can you create a snowflake using the â€œRepeatâ€ block to make a square 10 times, and the â€œTurnâ€ block to turn 36 degrees between each square?
instructions.grade4_playLab_proj_example1a_instructio: Take a look at this project. Do you see how it was made?
instructions.grade4_playLab_proj_example2a_instructio: Take a look at this project. Do you see how it was made?
instructions.grade4_playlab_freeplay_instruction: It's free play time! Have fun with all the blocks in your tool box.
instructions.grade4_playlab_test_instruction:
Use the right arrow to throw pie.

In our game, how should we score points? Add 1 to your "points" variable each time Dog hits Cat with a piece of pie. Use the "when actor 2 touches anything" event to trigger an update to your score. You can increment your variable by setting "points = points + 1." Get your score up to 10 (going one at a time!) to pass the level.
instructions.grade4_playlab_test2_instruction: Here's a function called jump that causes your main character to jump up 100 pixels. Run the program and use the jump function to collect all of the flags by moving the dog with the arrow keys.
instructions.grade4_prompt_test_instruction: This is a test play lab level.
instructions.grade4_review_artist1_instruction: Hi, I'm an artist. You can write code to make me draw almost anything. Use a few blocks to make me draw over the grey lines in the picture. (Each line is 100 pixels long)
instructions.grade4_review_artist2_instruction: This house needs a roof! Draw the triangle. Hint: all three sides are the same length.
instructions.grade4_review_artist3_instruction: The jump block moves the artist without drawing. Draw the dashed line using both the jump forward and move forward blocks. Each line is 50 pixels long.
instructions.grade4_review_bee1_instruction: Now use the repeat block to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
instructions.grade4_review_bee2_instruction: Collect nectar from each flower and make honey at each honeycomb using the fewest blocks possible.
instructions.grade4_review_bee3_instruction:
Such a busy bee!

Help bee collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey with the fewest blocks possible.
instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project1_instruction: It is amazing how much you have learned! Let's put them together to make a game, step by step.
instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project2_instruction:
Now let's get things moving! Use event handlers and actions to make your hero move.

We've added these blocks to your tool box to help you.
instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project3_instruction:
Now that your game has a hero, it's time to start adding other actors and assigning them behaviors.

Add two or more additional actors to your game and make them move. Do you want to have an actor patrol back and forth? Try using a these new blocks to bring these other components of your game to life!
instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project4_instruction: Just getting the actors moving is a great step, but we need to program some interactions to make this really feel like a game. A simple way to do this is to add or remove points when actors collide with projectiles or each other. Find some interesting ways to change the score in your game.
instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project4a_instruction: Just getting the actors moving is a great step, but we need to program some interactions to make this really feel like a game. A simple way to do this is to add or remove points when actors collide with projectiles or each other. Find some interesting ways to change the score in your game.
instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project5_instruction: Now spend some time making sure the game works the way you want. Try including a way to win or lose your game.
instructions.grade4_scaffolded_project6_instruction: You've finished! Now you can play your game or share it with your friends and classmates!
instructions.grade5_artist_binary1_instruction:
Binary is a way of representing information using only two options. Here, we're going to use the options "off" (represented by the number 0) and "on" (represented by the number 1).

We've provided you with a grid of "pixels" that you can walk through and make designs by turning on only certain squares. Can you have the artist draw "01010101" in binary in the first row?
instructions.grade5_artist_binary11_instruction: Free Play: Here's a blank canvas for you to draw on. Have fun!
instructions.grade5_artist_binary2_instruction:
Here's a function that takes a binary string of 1's and 0's and instructs the artist to follow them from left to right, top to bottom. The artist will fill-in the squares when it sees a 1 and ignore the square when it sees a 0.

Run this code to see how the artist uses binary to draw this pattern.
instructions.grade5_artist_binary3_instruction: Which of these binary strings could you loop 8 times to draw this image?
instructions.grade5_artist_binary4_instruction: Can you draw this pattern by looping just three binary digits (0s and 1s)?
instructions.grade5_artist_binary5_instruction: Each binary string represents one row of this picture. Can you rearrange them so it draws a smiley face instead of a frowny face?
instructions.grade5_artist_binary6_instruction: Which 6 digit binary string, repeated 11 times, will draw this image?
instructions.grade5_artist_binary7_instruction: What is the shortest binary string that you can repeat to draw this image?
instructions.grade5_artist_binary9_instruction:
Here's a higher resolution canvas to draw on - 16 pixels by 16 pixels!

See what happens when we start to get creative with the bits?
instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops1_instruction: Use a for loop to draw this triangle that is 50 pixels wide. If you count from 1 to 3 by 1s, you can use this just like a repeat loop.
instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops10_instruction:
Can you figure out how to use all of the things you've learned to create this image?

Need a hint? Click here.
instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops1a_instruction: Try using a for loopto create this triangular design. Don't worry that the numbers are different than the last puzzle. As long as you turn by the right number of degrees, the artist will make the correct shape!
instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops1b_instruction: Experiment with the for loop and play with the counter variable.
instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops2_instruction: Use a repeat inside of a for loop to create this stack of triangles that goes from 50 pixels to 100 pixels.
instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops3_instruction: These triangles go from 20 pixel sides to 200 pixel sides, and each triangle is 20 pixels larger than the last.
instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops4_instruction: These squares start at 15 pixels long, the largest is 300 pixels long, and each square is 15 pixels larger than the last.
instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops5_instruction:
Just one little change to the code from the last image can create this drawing. Can you figure out what that change is?

Hint: You need to remove something!
instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops6_instruction: If you turn a little bit more or less than you normally would for a shape, it creates a neat effect. Try using some of the code from the last level, but turning 89 degrees to create this twisted square spiral.
instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops7_instruction: Make three small changes to the code from the last level to get this!
instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops7a_instruction: Take the angle down to 72 degrees to get a spiraled pentagon.
instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops7b_instruction: Use the counter inside the set alpha block to get this faded center. (This hexagon pattern was made using a 60 degree turn.)
instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops8_instruction: Remember back in a previous stage when we used a variable to control the number of sides in a shape? We are going to do the same thing with the counter variable now. This pattern starts with a triangle and adds one side at a time until it draws a decagon (10 sides). Each side should be 100 pixels long.
instructions.grade5_artist_for_loops9_instruction:
Let's put it all together! Using your knowledge of for loops and the counter variable, create this drawing where each shape has two more sides than the last. Make sure that each side is 10 times as long as the number of sides in the polygon.

Very little of the code has been provided for you.
instructions.grade5_artist_for_loopsfreeplay11_instru:
Free-Play Inspiration: You've now learned everything you need to know to make a pattern like this! If this picture inspires you, try to make something similar. Otherwise, create something all your own.

Need a hint? Click here.
instructions.grade5_artist_for_loopsfreeplay12_instru: Free Play: Try using the counter variable with other drawing elements to make magical images like this one.
instructions.grade5_artist_freeplay_instruction: Create your own project! This creation will be saved to your Projects dashboard so that you can easily edit it any time!
instructions.grade5_artist_functionparameters10_instr:
Free Play Inspiration: You've now learned everything you need to know to make a pattern like this! If this picture inspires you, try to make something similar. Otherwise, create something all your own.

Want to know how our inspiration pattern was made?
instructions.grade5_artist_functionparameters11_instr: Freeplay: Below there are functions you've written, and more for you to play with. Draw something awesome! Play with the pen width to see how different your drawings look!
instructions.grade5_artist_functionparameters7_instru: This image is similar to the last. Can you use a for loop with your function to make this design?
instructions.grade5_artist_functionparameters8_instru: The triangle has 21 pixel sides, and the sides in each following shape are 7 pixels longer than the last. Use the multiplication block to make this all happen with just one function call. Be sure to jump 100 pixels between polygons.
instructions.grade5_artist_functionparameters9_instru: Challenge: Edit draw a spiral edge to use length and sides parameters, then recreate these shapes.
instructions.grade5_artist_functionparameters9a_instr: Finish off the draw a spiral edge function to also ask for a minimum length for the center of the spiral.
instructions.grade5_artist_functionparameters9b_instr: Can you figure out how to make this drawing using the function that you just created?
instructions.grade5_artist_functionparameters_6_instr:
Edit this function to add a parameter for the number of sides in your polygon.

The sides of all the shapes are 100 pixels long.
instructions.grade5_artist_parameters_squares1_instru: Click "edit" to fill in the function definition of "draw a square" and add a parameter. It should take a length parameter, just like the triangle. This time, draw 3 squares: 25, 50 and 75 pixels in length, each 100 pixels apart.
instructions.grade5_artist_parameters_squares1a_instr: This program looks okay from here, but something isn't working right. See if you can figure out how to edit the function 'draw a square' to find the bug.
instructions.grade5_artist_parameters_squares2_instru: Create a function called 'draw a square' and use it to outline these four boxes. Make sure to add a parameter for 'length'! Starting from the upper right, the box widths are 50, 100, 150, and 200.
instructions.grade5_artist_parameters_squares2a_instr: Edit the function to accept a parameter called length.
instructions.grade5_artist_parameters_stars1_instruct: That last one is tough if you only use loops. Let's try drawing the same picture using this new 'function' that will help to draw a star.
instructions.grade5_artist_parameters_triangles1_inst: This program looks okay from here, but something isn't working right. See if you can figure out how to edit the function 'draw a square' to find the bug.
instructions.grade5_artist_parameters_triangles1a_ins: Today, we're going to try out a different, more powerful function editor. See if you can figure out how to edit the function 'draw a triangle' to find the bugs.
instructions.grade5_artist_parameters_triangles1aa_in: Click "edit" to fill in the function definition of "draw a triangle" and add a parameter. It should take a length parameter, just like the triangle. This time, draw 3 triangles: 25, 50 and 75 pixels in length, each 100 pixels apart.
instructions.grade5_artist_parameters_triangles2_inst: This drawing can be easily created using a new type of function that includes a parameter. The sides of each triangle are 25 pixels larger than the last. The first triangle has 25 pixel sides. Replace the '???' with the correct values to draw the picture.
instructions.grade5_artist_parameters_triangles2a_ins: Do you notice anything different about these function blocks? Click â€œRunâ€ to see what happens.
instructions.grade5_artist_parameters_triangles3_inst:
The code for this triangle function is broken.

Can you edit the function to fix it, and then make triangles of length 150, 75, 25?
instructions.grade5_artist_parameters_triangles4_inst: The code for this triangle function is broken. Can you edit the function to fix it, and then make triangles of length 25, 50, and 75?
instructions.grade5_artist_parameters_trianglesy_inst:
The code for this triangle function is broken.

Can you edit the function to fix it, and then make triangles of length 150, 75, 25?
instructions.grade5_artist_variables_freeplay10_instr: Free Play: Experiment with the number of sides this shape has. Can you change the algorithm so that the overall size of the shape stays the same, no matter how many sides it has? Hint: If you divide your starting length by the number of sides, the length of each side will get shorter as the number of sides gets higher.
instructions.grade5_artist_variables_freeplay14_instr:
Free Play: Check it out! Now your algorithm is nested within one more loop. Experiment with changing the values of your two variables to draw cool patterns.

For even more effect, try playing with color! Use random colors inside loops to see how it changes your design.
instructions.grade5_artist_variables_freeplay15_instr:
Want a second peek at the inspiration design or the hints? Click here!

Otherwise, make a design all your own!
instructions.grade5_artist_variables_freeplay16_instr: Still playing? Here is a blank canvas where you can create whatever you want!
instructions.grade5_artist_variables_hexagons1_instru:
Let's try it again!

Can you set the length variable to 60 to make this cool design with hexagons?
instructions.grade5_artist_variables_letterT11_instru: Hereâ€™s more complicated code using the same concepts from the last puzzle - what should you set the "sides" variable to in order to draw this picture made of squares?
instructions.grade5_artist_variables_new1_instruction: Here is a program that will create an image. There are a few things that are wrong with it.
instructions.grade5_artist_variables_octagons13_instr: When a shape has lots of sides, each side needs to be shorter if you want the whole pattern to fit on the screen. Let's recreate the algorithm for this amazing pattern, but instead of manually setting the length variable, let's use a math block with the sides variable inside to make sure that each shape fits correctly. The perimeter of each polygon is 300 pixels. Need some hints? Click here.
instructions.grade5_artist_variables_pentagon8_instru:
Use what you learned in the last puzzle to create this hexagon using the "sides" variable.

See how you could change just one value to draw a triangle, square, pentagon, or octagon?
instructions.grade5_artist_variables_pentagon9_instru: Now, recreate the algorithm from the last level and create a pentagon with sides of length 150.
instructions.grade5_artist_variables_pentagons1_instr:
Draw this pattern of pentagons with 100 pixel sides by setting the right value for length and dropping the length variable into all of the the correct places.

See how you only have to set the value for length once, and the code uses the right value everywhere?
instructions.grade5_artist_variables_pentagons12_inst: Let's set the "sides" variable to 5. The more sides we add to this algorithm, the bigger this whole pattern gets! Notice that there is another variable called "length". We can now use that wherever we have a "move forward." Set the "length" variable to 75 for this shape.
instructions.grade5_artist_variables_rectangle6_instr: Now I want to make a rectangle that is twice as tall as it is wide. We've got a variable called "width" that needs to be set to 100. Can you use the math blocks to complete the code?
instructions.grade5_artist_variables_square7_instruct:
Hereâ€™s some code that can draw any regular polygon. Thereâ€™s a new variable called sides that is set to 4. Can you use the sides variable (along with the math block) to turn the right amount regardless of how many sides there are in the polygon?

Click here to go back to the hint!
instructions.grade5_artist_variables_triangles2_instr: Instead of using "move forward by 150," the "move" block is now referencing a variable called "length." Can you set "length" to 150 to draw this new triangle?
instructions.grade5_artist_variables_triangles3_instr: Drag a number block to both the set length block and the repeat _ times block to draw a set of 50 pixel triangles.
instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops1_instruction: Use a loop to collect the nectar from each flower.
instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops10_instruction: What should your increment be to collect 15, then 12, then 9, 6, 3 nectar?
instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops11_instruction: Challenge: Take what you've learned about for loops and try to solve this problem.
instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops2_instruction: Add the code necessary to make sure the bee collects all the nectar. Look at how much code you need for this puzzle! (We'll learn a simpler way in the next puzzle.)
instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops3_instruction: Try this puzzle using the for loop with counter variable and see how much shorter your code becomes.
instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops4_instruction: Help the bee collect all of the nectar.
instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops6_instruction: You can also use a "for loop" to count down. Try gathering this nectar by counting down from 5 to 1 by 1.
instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops7_instruction: Try collecting these flowers using an increment of 2.
instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops8_instruction: You've got this! What should your increment be to collect 3, 6, 9, 12, 15 nectar?
instructions.grade5_bee_for_loops9_instruction: Use the counter variable to navigate this garden with the fewest number of blocks possible.
instructions.grade5_bee_parameters_new8_instruction: That's a great function you've created! You are officially on your own now. Collect all the nectar. Make all the honey.
instructions.grade5_bee_parameters_new9_instruction: Bonus Challenge! If you are feeling ambitious, try this puzzle. It is possible to collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey using only a For loop, a Repeat loop, a function call, and a turn. Try it all on your own, or view the hints to build it step-by-step. Great job with this stage!
instructions.grade5_pixelation_instruction: Encode an image of anything you like using binary. The binary language will be represented with '0' and '1' only.
instructions.grade5_playlab_freeplay_instruction: It's free play time! Have fun with all the blocks in your tool box.
instructions.grade5_playlab_parameters_points1_instru:
Here's the same game but most of the code is hidden. We've added a new function called score_points.

Add a new parameter called points to the player_score function.

The score_points function should be able to both add and remove points from player_score depending on which actor is hit. Changing the score by 1 will add a point, while changing the score by -1 will subtract a point.

When you're done, click "Run" to play. When Dog scores 6 points, you will move on to the next puzzle.
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables1_instruction: This time you don't have to write any code, just hit "Run" to play the game! In this game, you're the dog who is trying to collect more flags than the cat. Use the down arrow to control the dog. Press "Finish" when you're done playing.
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables10_instruction: Edit the the "patrol" function to add an "actor" parameter, so that we can call it for each of the actors on the screen. Remember, the actors correspond to numbers 1, 2, and 3.
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables11_instruction: Add another parameter called "speed" to the "patrol" function. Try using a "set speed" block with the new "speed" parameter to help Penguin get both flags before the other sprites even get one.
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables12_instruction:
Let's have some fun! Look at the code provided to see if you can figure out what each block does.
When you're done, use the arrow keys to control Dog and collect all of the flags. NOTE: You don't need to make any changes to the program
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables13_instruction: Use the when actor touches block to send Dog back to the top-left ONLY if Dog touches any of the other actors.
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables14_instruction: It's free play time! Have fun with all the blocks in your tool box.
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables1ask_instruction:
This time, when you press 'run', you will see a 'prompt' asking you for a number. This number will be stored in a variable used to set the dog's speed.

Pay attention to how this program is written!
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables2_instruction: The race in that last puzzle wasn't very fair! Change the dog_speed variable to make sure you can collect more flags than Cat. The first to collect 10 flags wins!
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables3_instruction: Use the left and right arrows to move, and the up arrow to jump. See if you can collect all of the flags.
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables4_instruction: Now we're using a variable called "height" to control how high the dog can jump. Update the "height" variable so that the dog can jump high enough to reach all the flags.
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables5_instruction:
You've seen now how a variable can be used to set the height of an actor's jump. How else could you use a variable?

Let's build a game! First we'll need a score. Try setting the 'points' variable to give yourself 10 free points!
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables6_instruction:
Use the right arrow to throw pie.

In our game, how should we score points? Add 1 to your "points" variable each time Dog hits Cat with a piece of pie. Use the "when actor 2 touches anything" event to trigger an update to your score. You can increment your variable by setting "points = points + 1." Get your score up to 10 (going one at a time!) to pass the level.
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables6ask_instruction: This time, you need 100 points to win! Don't worry though, you can choose how many points you earn each time you score a hit! Try adding the ask block and changing the number 1 out for the variable value.
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables7_instruction: Nice, now let's make sure this game isn't too easy to play. Any time Dog (actor 1) gets hit by a sandwich from Cat (actor 2), you should lose a point. Start with 10 points so it's not too hard. Let your score drop down from 10 to 0 to pass the level.
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables71_instruction:
Here's our game from an earlier stage, but most of the code is hidden. Thereâ€™s a new function score_points.

Edit the function so that a new parameter called points can be added to player_score.

The variable player_score should increase each time Dog tags Cat with pie, and decrease each time that Cat tags Dog with a sandwich.

Note: When you're done, click "Run" to play. When Dog scores 6 points, you will move on to the next puzzle.
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables81_instruction:
We've added one last function for you.

Use an "if" statement to program your game to call the "level_up" function only when "player_score" becomes greater than a certain number.

For example: "player_score" > 6

Play the game, and make it to level 3 to move to the next puzzle.
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables9_instruction:
Here's a function called patrol.

Edit patrol to move Cat up 400 pixels and then down 400 pixels.
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables_freeplay_instru:
Free Play time! Here are all of the variables we've played with so far in this stage, as well as a few more in case you want them.

Notice that there are now so many blocks in our toolbox that they need to be organized! Here, we've put each piece into an appropriate category. Take some time to explore everything that is available. When you're done browsing, make a game or story using repeats, variables, and events.

Hint: scroll down to see all the commands in the workspace.
instructions.grade5_playlab_variables_jump1_instructi: This puzzle uses a hidden function that makes the dog jump when the 'up' arrow is pressed. The height of the jumps can be set at the start of the game using the 'jumpPower' variable. Try to touch all of the flags!
instructions.grade5_prompt_test_instruction: Variables aren't always numbers. What if you wanted to store a word or text? Experiment with the new ask block.

instructions.loop pet test_instruction:
Last time, you practiced using the "repeat forever" loop to make a sprite do something forever. This time, we will use it to make a virtual pet.

This dog's name is Daisy. Daisy LOVES to snack on carrots. Use the "drag and drop" block to move the carrot to Daisy.

instructions.mike3bitmario_instruction:
A careless binary coder typed in ONE extra 0 or 1 somewhere within this image's data. The extra bit that is causing Mario to glitch out!

Delete the extra bit to restore Mario back to normal!
instructions.pet game 1_instruction: Use the "make a new sprite" block to make yourself a pet!
instructions.pet game 2_instruction: Your pet needs some exercise! Use the "add behavior" block to get them moving.
instructions.pet game 3_instruction: Pets love toys! Use a second "make sprite" block to give your pet a toy, then use the "move towards" behavior to make your pet run to their new toy.
instructions.pet game 4_instruction:
When your pet gets to their toy, they get excited! Use the "when touches" block to detect when your pet gets to their toy.

When that happens, use the "remove behavior" block to make them stop walking, and the "add behavior" block to make them have a dance party!
instructions.pet game 5_instruction: You can add lots more things for your pet to interact with! Play around with the "set sprite" block and make more stuff anywhere you want it!
instructions.pet game 6_instruction: It's important for pets to learn to follow commands. Use the "when clicked" block to teach your pet to only start wandering after you click on them.
instructions.pet game 7_instruction: Pets need to learn to stop, too! Use the "when clicked" block to teach your pet to stop wandering after you click on them.
instructions.pet game 8_instruction: Your pet now has two toys! Use the "when clicked" block to get them to move to the toy you click on
instructions.pet game 9_instruction: Your pet has been so good, they deserve a treat. Use the "add behavior" block to make the bone draggable, then drag it to your pet.
